editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As It Is ACTED At the THEATRE-ROYAL in Drury-Lane. By His MAJESTY's Company of COMEDIANS.

q.p: It is a Kind of Slander, to trust to RUMOUR.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for T. PAYNE, near Stationers-Hall, M.DCC.XXIII. [Price 1 s. 6 d.]

div.head: TO ERASMUS EARLE, Esq
div.p:
THE Weak naturally fly to the Brave for Protection; and, methinks, a Play in which a Soldier carries off the Prize, has a sort of Right to a Patron out of the Camp. Your condescending to serve, for some little Time, as Subaltern Officer, while You are in the actual Possession of so Noble a Paternal Estate, is equally Admir'd, and Applauded, by All who have the Happiness to know You. This is
truly doing an Honour to the British Service; And how much is it to be desir'd, that so Bright an Example, may be Imitated by other Gentlemen of the best Families, and Fortunes.

We have scarce an Instance in Antient, or Modern History, of any Hero who has Commanded WELL, without having first learn'd what it was to OBEY. The Greatest among the Greek and Roman Generals, made their First Campaigns in the Nature of Voluntiers; and the Greatest Modern Hero, whose Loss we so lately lamented, serv'd first in the same Post You now Adorn.

IF a Fine Person, a most Graceful, and Easy Behaviour, joyn'd to a great Knowledge of the World, and a general Insight into all Parts of Polite Learning, are the most likely Means to raise a Man to Greatness,
I know not what Bounds You can reasonably set to Your Ambition! One Thing I am well assur'd of, That it will be a Happiness to your Country, to see You in some of her Highest Military Honours.

I confess, I am glad to lay hold of any Opportunity of paying my Early Court to so distinguish'd a Merit; and hope, Sir, That my laying this Trifle at Your Feet, however poor it may be in itself, will be at least some small Proof of that Zeal and Respect, with which I am,

closer.signed: Your Most Obedient, and Most Humble Servant, SUSANNA CENT-LIVRE.

lg.l: OUR Wits of late, grown wond'rous Weather-wise,
Change, like the various Seasons of the Skies.
They, each dull Winter, Sullen and Severe,
And Cloudy, as its Gloomyest Days appear:
Yawn o'er their Desks, sigh forth some Tragick-Scene,
Then Treat the Town with Products of their Spleen.
Our Author takes a different Way to please;
Heals Injur'd Love, and Cures its Jealousies.
You Tender Virgins, and Neglected Wives,
For You, She all her ARTIFICE contrives.
You can't deny her — Your Protection, surely,
She hides your Slips, and brings you off—so purely!
Bold in her Sex's Cause, She always rouzes
'Gainst their Worst Foes, False Lovers, and Dull Spouses.
But, oh! ye Criticks! Comic-Bards are few,
And we've no Wit beneath the Sun, that's New:
Ask not, in such a General Dearth, much Wit,
If she your Taste in Plot, and Humour hit:
Plot, Humour, Business, form the Comick Feast,
Wit's but a higher-relish'd Sawce, at best;
And where too much, like Spice, destroys the Taste.
You Sparks in Red, she knows, will all befriend her;
Nay, Faith, You're bound in Honour to defend her.
You, in her Plays, her choicest Favours share;
She never fails to raise her Men of War.
'Tis seldom known, You Brothers of the Blade,
Let Women make Advances Un-repaid.
You Chiefs in War, that Monarchs can subdue,
Yet own —The Ladies Victors over You.
A Single Helen, once Divinely Fair,
Summon'd a Croud of Heroes to the War:
And Brighter Helens raise your Courage —There.
You, while our Author pleads in Beauty's Cause,
Join on her Side, and Arm in her Applause:
Be Heroes in a Woman's Cause to Day,
And as you Love the Sex, Defend the Play.

list.head: MEN.
list.label: Sir Philip Money-Love, Father to Olivia, a Man whose Morals are only subservient to his Interest
Sir John Freeman, Heir to 4000 l. per Annum, but disinherited. In Love with Olivia
Ned Freeman, His Younger Brother; possess'd of the Estate
Fainwell, An Ensign under the Name of Jeffery; in Disguise, a Footman to the Widow Headless
Mr. Watchit, A Country-Gentleman, very jealous of his Wife
Tally, One belonging to a Pharoah-Bank; an Humble Servant to Widow Headless, under the Character of Lord Pharoah-Bank
Demur, A Doctor of the Law.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.label: Olivia, Daughter of Sir Philip Money-love. In Love with Sir John Freeman.
Louisa, a Dutch Lady, formerly contracted to Ned Freeman
Mrs. Watchit, Wife to Mr. Watchit
Widow Headless, worth 20,000 l. an affected vain Widow, an Admirer of Quality, and resolv'd never to marry beneath a Lord
Lucy, Servant to Mrs. VVatchit
Flora, Servant to Louisa
Judith, Servant to Mrs. Headless
Constable, Watch, and other Attendants.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE the PARK.
div.stage: Enter Fainwell in a Livery, meeting Sir John Freeman in Mourning.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: HA! Freeman in Black? Dear Jack, how must I distinguish thee?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dear Jack! —How came you and I so well acquainted, Fellow?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Oh! — that's too long a Story at present.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fainwell! — what the Devil is this Metamorphose for?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Love! Almighty Love! Copying of the Gods, you know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What Game are you in Pursuit of?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: The old standing Dish, a WIFE! Here's no Hopes of War, no Rising in View! and Subaltern's Pay will make a Man rub but slowly through the World. I have got Leave of my Colonel to be absent from my Post for Two Months, in which Time, I intend to make my Fortune. —You know the Widow Headless!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very well! Ha! —is not that her Livery?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I march in the Number of her Retinue.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To what End?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That's uncertain. If you know the Widow, you are no Stranger to her Taste in Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I know she keeps none but awkard Country Things.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay! and is a perfect Jockey in her Family, and takes as much Pains to polish her Train, as they do to break their young Colts. Now, you must know, I pass with her for as arrant a Rustick, as ever wielded Cudgel at a Country Wake, or tumbled Girl upon a Hay-mow.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But wherein can this advance your Design?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why, you must know, I make Love to her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Make Love to her! what, under the Character of a Footman?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, no, under the Character of a Gentleman of Fifteen hundred Pounds a Year in Gloucester-shire, of which Country I pretend to be; for having Quarter'd heretofore in that Shire, I counterfeit the Dialect very well.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But what Service can this be to you?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why, I write to her as from Mr. Worthy; my Man brings the Letters; and I deliver them as Jeffrey, her Footman; and when I find her in Humour, I intend to give her my Picture, in so simple a Manner, that she shall take it all for Gospel.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But what signifies the Copy? How will you introduce the Original?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That has been done already. I have made her several Visits. My Man is now gone to her with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But suppose she should enquire after this Mr. Worthy? It is an easy Matter to know all the Gentlemen in Gloucestershire, and what Estates they are possess'd of too.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: She can't trap me there, if she does: For, between you and I, there is such a Person as Mr. Worthy, Master of the very Estate I mention, who has given me Leave to take his Name. — But I have discover'd since I have been in her House, that an Irish Baron is my Rival.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Then you are undone; for I am told, she declares against Matrimony without a Title. Who is he?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: My Lord Pharoah-Bank, I think they call him, of the County of Tipperary.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I don't remember ever to have heard of any such Nobleman.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Recommended, they say, by Sir Philip Money-Love.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: For which he is to have a valuable Consideration; for I am sure, he does nothing out of Honour or Honesty. I wish thee Success with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I thank you, Freeman; but prithee, who are you in Mourning for? Is the old Knight at Rest Six Foot deep? ha, Jack?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: He has been dead to me these Seven Years; but is now so to all the World, Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Sir John! I give thee Joy of Four thousand Pounds per Annum. Embracing him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope you'll give me the Estate too, Fainwell; for, I assure you, I have not one Foot of Land by the Death of my Father.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: He did not disinherit thee, sure.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Neither better nor worse.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I ever thought my old Master would dye hard, and take the Left-hand Road.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! what is Sam with you still?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You know, Sir, I always stick as close to my Masters, as their Breeches.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay! whilst there is any Money in them; but, I remember, you left me for fear of Starving.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Starving! Oh, no, no! — Not Starving, Sir; though, I must confess, my Waist-band was Three Inches too wide for me.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: You saucy Rascal! ha, ha? Well, did you deliver my Letter?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, I did Sir; and into the Widow's own Hands; and, truly, by what I can find, Sir▪, you have nothing to hope for, if I have any Judgment.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why? What have you discover'd?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why, I observ'd when she read your Epistle, she smil'd scornfully, thus —toss'd your Letter upon her Toylet; turn'd upon her Heel; tipp'd her Maid a Box o' the Ear for Grinning, and bad me tell you, it required no Answer.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Cold Comfort!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Not a Jot the less, for giving herself that Air. But is it possible, that pure Party-Rage could make thy Father so unkind, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Add to that some little Wildnesses. But the main thing that did my Business, was this; When I found nothing wou'd open his Purse-strings, I pretended to embrace his Principles.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I remember that Time, Sir: We lived in Clover then! Many a delicious Morsel of Flesh have I serv'd up, and supp'd luxuriously out of your Leavings, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But, as the Devil wou'd have it, one Day, in my Cups, I chanced to stumble into a Non-juring Meeting, with half a Dozen honest Officers at my Back, drove out the Congregation, ty'd the Parson Neck and Heels, lock'd the Door, and took the Key in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Good! And what became of Old Sedition?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Some of his Flock returning to Evening. Prayer, broke open the Door, and freed him from Durance; amongst which Number was my natural Father.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Rather Unnatural! That was very unlucky, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay; for that Action not only lost me a paternal Blessing, but a paternal Estate.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Which would have afforded thee many Blessings, Wine and Women, Sir John, the only Blessings in this World! So your younger Brother Ned has the Estate, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Every Acre! My Fortune is cramm'd into such a Narrow Circumference, I can cover it with my Thumb. Only —a single Shilling.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Damn'd Barbarity! 'S' Death! were he my Brother, I'd cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: There's the Inside of a Soldier for you! aside.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: So say Passion and Necessity; but Conscience and Humanity offer to my cooler Thoughts a brown Musquet rather. I confess, I long to exert the elder Brother, and beat him a little; In order to which, I have done all I could to provoke him to give me Occasion; but he avoids me as carefully as if he durst not fight, though I know he's no Coward.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Well! Heaven be prais'd, I am not afraid of being disinherited. I wear my Fortune with my Red Coat; and whilst there is one Mischief-making Priest in the World, Soldiers will never want Bread.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ay, the Priests have ever been fast Friends to the Soldiers. Nothing like a Pulpit-Drum. —But it ruins the Surgeons Business quite.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay! how so?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why, where's the Occasion for their retailing Lancet, when the other lets the Nation Blood by Wholesale?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: My Rascal has a kind of smattering after Wit, ha, ha. No more of your Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Impertinence! these Gentlemen will allow no body to say a good Thing but themselves. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! yonder's my Brother coming this Way. How stately the Rogue walks, with Three Footmen at his Heels!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Whilst thou hast not so much as one Scoundrel, to pick up a Wench for thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, for that, Sir! with your Leave, he may always command his humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: He struts like an elder Brother. He wants nothing but your Title, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I wish I could transfer it; for it is of no Use to me. Honour's a Commodity not vendable among the Merchants; there is no Draw-back upon't.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That's a Mistake, Sir John; I have known a Statesman pawn his Honour as often as Merchants enter the same Commodity for Exportation; and like them, draw it back so cleverly, that those who give him Credit upon't, never perceiv'd it 'till the Great Man was out of Post.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Honour's a stale Cheat.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: It may pass at Court, or the Groom-Porter's; but no Citizen will lend a Shilling upon it.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Brother! Your Servant. If this young Fellow had not been in a Livery, I should have sworn it had been Ensign Fainwell!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
The very Numerical Person you mention, is as you see, at your Service, Mr. Freeman. I believe you are surpriz'd at the Figure I make; but there are Reasons, which another time shall be yours. In the
mean while, I must intreat, that wherever you see me, you know me for nothing above my present Appearance.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Whatever Design you may have in View, it shall never miscarry through any Fault of mine.— Well! how go Matters in the North, Captain?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your Party perform'd no Wonders there.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Nay, if you are entring upon Party Matters, good by-t'ye; You know I always decline Politicks in your Company.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Tis the Sign of an ill Cause.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Then Disputes won't mend it. Here — which Colour would you advise me to for a Wedding Suit?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: What! just upon the Brink of Matrimony? Is it with the Dutch Lady you wrote such Panegyricks on, when you was in Holland?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What, the old Burgo-master's Daughter of Haerlem? No, no! that Affair's ended long since. She was a good natur'd fond Fool, and, to say Truth, I did love her; but the old Carl her Father, did not like a younger Brother for a Son-in-Law then, and I'm a better Friend to my Country, than to take a Dutch Wife now. I did him one Piece of Service; I left some English Blood in his Family. I met a Gentleman at Paris, who told me, she was brought to Bed of a fine Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If I mistake not, you made that Lady a Promise of Marriage, Brother.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Cou'd I do less for a Maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: It is the Custom in Holland, after such a Promise, the Girl never scruples to go to Bed, and thinks herself as much your Wife, as if the Parson had said Grace; and if ever you are found in that Country, their Laws will oblige you to perform Articles.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ay, if they catch me in the Corn, let 'em put me in the Pound.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Whatever you think of such Proceedings, I assure you, I should have very little Confidence in
that Man who forfeited his Faith and Honour to a Woman.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Preserve your Opinion, Brother; the Ladies will like you never the better for't. Every Female has Vanity enough to believe her Charms sufficient to secure what another lost.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: But who is the Object of your present Passion?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pray Heaven, it proves not where I guess! Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Who is the Beauty that inslaves you now?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Nay, I'm not so prodigiously inslav'd as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What! and just going to be Married?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Mr. Freeman speaks like an experienc'd Traveller; he is entring upon a Journey for Life; the Whip, and Spur, are for the short Stages of Love. It would kill the Devil to ride full Speed down a Lane that has neither End nor Turning.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Sam has a right Notion of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A Lady must be extremely happy with such a Husband. But may we not know the Lady?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, Brother, I'm not asham'd of the Lady; she has Beauty enough for a Wife, and One Charm, as desirable, as a New Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Twenty thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! that one Article strikes through me.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir Philip Money-Love's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: As I imagin'd! — This Blow wounds deeper, than my being disinherited. Have you that Lady's Consent, Brother?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I have her Father's, and he has the Disposal of her Fortune, though left by her Grandfather. She commands not a Penny, if she marries without his Consent.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
A most pernicious Clause! —Yet, if Louisa his Dutch Mistress, who I have sent for, comes
Time enough, I may chance to spoil your Market.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I think I stand very fair; I have had his Promise these Ten Days.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Just the Time that Sir Philip forbid me his House; since when, I have often watch'd him in, and fearing the Consequence, I sent for his Mistress; and if there is the least Grain of Vertue left in that Heap of Muck and Immorality, Sir Philip, I may yet prevent this hateful Match. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I wish you Joy, Mr. Freeman.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Wish him Hell! where he may Taste in part the Pains he gives me now. — Olivia!— Oh! my Olivia!— Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: My Brother has no Relish for my good Fortune. — I perceive you affect Gravity in my Company, Sir John, and seem to have no Taste for any Joy of mine,— Prithee, how have I offended? You may have Reason to blame our Father, perhaps; but how is that my Fault? I have really as much Love for you, as if you had been born a Year after me, and will treat you as well.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That is to say, he shall live like your Brother.—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: He shall live as he thinks fit, Sir; I shan't pretend to direct him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: But you must put it in his Power! — Come, shall I make a Proposal?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Buy him a Colonel's Post in the Guards.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I don't think to part with any Money that way.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not without it were to serve a certain Person, you know where. Oh! that vile, restless Principle of yours!—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Shall never disturb you with a Commission any where. Look ye, Brother, you shan't want for what is Necessary.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Necessary! I suppose you reserve to your own Judgment how far that Word may extend.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: It shall extend so far, Sir, as becomes a Brother who has the Estate, to him that has none.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Humph! That is as much as to say, in plain English, you may Starve or Steal, and be Hang'd, for Him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: As far as becomes your Elder Brother?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I can't say that, for perhaps you may fancy my Estate may become you better than it does me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your Estate! Going up to him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: [Stepping between.] Sir, Sir, With your Leave! Where-abouts do you think the Soul of my old Master may be now?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: That Thought never enter'd my Head, Sirrah. I know where his material Soul, the Estate is, and how to Spend it too. So, Brother, if you will be Chearful. —.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Chearful! Bid the Directors, when there's a Run upon the Bank, be Chearful; the Merchant who hears the Shipwreck of his freighted Vessel; or bid the Mother, weeping o'er the Corps of her departed Son, be Chearful.—Bid them be Mad, rather, to avoid Reflection.—Chearful, Quotha?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That's breaking a Man's Legs, and then bidding him cut Capers. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Philosophy is a noble Study, Sir John ▪ but few of us poor Rogues can pursue it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With what Elegance might my Brother there, display the Beauty of Patience and Poverty?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No, Faith, Jack, I am no Orator.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh! What Serenity of Mind attends Four Thousand Pounds a Year? whilst Passion, Pride, and all the Deadly-Sins, fill up the Train of a poor Dog, like me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That's true to a Tittle, I know it by my self. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Poor Olivia! now I understand thy Letter, wherein thou saidst, That we must part for Ever; but I will see Thee now, tho' certain Death attend it; tho' robb'd of Birthright by this younger Brother, let him not hope to take my Mistress from me.—
sp.l: Such an Attempt will far more dang'rous prove:
He robs me of my Life, that robs me of my Love.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: That is the Colour for my Money.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay, White is the Bridegroom's Colour.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha! What is my Brother gone?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So it seems — Poor Sir John! —

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Pox of this Livery, I shou'd have been glad we cou'd have Din'd together to Day.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Now you talk of Dining—your Uncle call'd at your Lodging this Morning, Sir, and bad me tell you, he wonders how you bestow your Time, that you don't come and Dine with him as usual.—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: An Uncle of mine, to whom I had once some hopes of being Heir.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And what has stifled them?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why, the Devil put Matrimony in his Head, and spoil'd my Fortune.—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Then he has Children, has he?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: One, which happening to be Red-hair'd, and the Parson of the Parish being Sandy, my Uncle, not content with forbidding him his House, bid adieu to the Country, and brought my Aunt to Town.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: An excellent Place to preserve Vertue in.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: How came he to suspect the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why, my Aunt is a Roman Catholick, you must know, and I suppose my Uncle had a mind to make a good Protestant of her, and brought the Doctor to Convert her; but finding his Arguments more prevalent for Love, than Religion, thought fit to remove her.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Where has he Lodg'd her?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: He has taken a House in the Pall-Mall, within a Door of my Colonel's.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Who has as good a hand at Converting, as the Parson, if he can find a way to come at her. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: In the Pall-Mall! If this shou'd be my Mistress now? [Aside.] So, the old Fellow is very Jealous of her, you say?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So Jealous, that he locks her up, it seems, resolving to Father no Children for the future, but his own; He allows her the Sight of nothing that's Male.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: It must be she; this agrees exactly with her Story. [Aside.] Such Restraint sets all the Wheels of Invention at Work, and a Million to Nothing, but she'll find a way to use him as he deserves. And how does she take it?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh! not at all Sir,—You hear my Master say, she's Lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Her Confinement, I mean, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh! her Confinement.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Not seeing her the last Time I din'd there, I inquir'd after her Health, and was answer'd, she was Indispos'd; yet I observ'd he cut her a Plate of ev'ry thing that came to the Table, and sent up to her Chamber, which, as the Maid told me afterwards, is his constant Custom of late, when any body Dines with him. He is a true Spanish Husband.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And if she proves but a true English Wife, his Children may be nothing a-kin to him, for all his Caution. Is she handsome?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So handsome, that I could venture my Soul with her; and if I had her Consent, my Uncle Watchit, should be advanced in Honours.—You understand me.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Watchit! Mum! that's the Name. Fainwell must not know where I live. [Aside.] — You would not Cuckold your Uncle, would ye?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
Why not? I think a well bred Gentleman ought to have as much regard to the Breed of his
Family, as a Fox-Hunter has to those of his Dogs and Horses. Where do you Lodge, Mr. Freeman? I must bring a School-Fellow of mine to wait on you, one who has a Play upon the Stocks: You must give him leave to Dedicate to you. It is young Distich.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha! Little Distich! I shall be glad to see him. When I have finish'd an Affair which I have upon my Hands at present, I shall come somewhere to this End of the Town; but I am Incog. for a little while.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: What, are you upon an Intrigue?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, Faith, and with one of the prettiest Women in Town; a Citizen's Wife, whose Husband is Tinctur'd with thy Uncle's Distemper: He permits her neither to pay, or receive Visits; but in spight of his Blockade, I have found means to open a Communication between my Self and his Female, and hope I shall be able to spring a Mine, and blow up the Fort of her Chastity, maugre all his Iron Guards.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: You talk like an Engineer, Mr. Freeman; but if she is so closely confin'd, how got you acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Very accidentally. You must know, her House, and That which I lodge in, were formerly one, so that there are Doors remaining, tho' fasten'd up—Sitting one Evening in my Chamber reading, I heard the Voice of Women, and found by their Discourse 'twas a Lady complaining to her Maid of her Husband's ill Usage. If I were in your place, says the Maid, I'd be reveng'd of the old Brute: Ay, quoth the Lady, but shew me the Means.—Upon which, having bor'd a Hole in the Door, I put my Mouth to it, and cry'd, The Means is ready, Madam, if you'll Consent to it. She was a little surpriz'd at first, but we soon came to a right Understanding.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ha, ha! so she open'd the Door!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Not that Door: But the Chamber-Maid, who knew her Business perfectly well, after inquiring who Lodg'd at next House? in the Morning, knock'd
gently at this private Door, and calling me by my Name, gave me to understand, that there was a Door, between her Room, and a Garret in our House, which if I cou'd find the way to open, I might have an Opportunity of playing a Game at Picquet with her Lady sometimes, in her Master's Absence: I took the Hint, agreed with my Landlord for that Garret, and fell to work immediately. The Passage was soon open'd, and we came to an Interview, lik'd one another's Proposals, call'd for the Cards, and sat down to Play, where I had the Game all to Nothing, having Point, Quint, and Quatorze, the first Deal, had not the old Fellow come in, and forc'd us to throw up our Cards.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: For which you both curs'd him, I suppose; but you have found a Time, 'tis to be hop'd, to finish your Game.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I shall do, this Day, I believe. Wish me Success, Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I do with all my Heart: I know you us'd to be Generous, you'll not expose her. When you have corrupted her, you may help your Friends, before she falls into the Hands of the Publick.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: With all my Heart! Now for the finishing Stroke: I'll Home, and watch the old Fellow out, and then L'Affair il sera fait, as the French say— Which way are you going, Fainwell?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Every way! I have some Twenty How-d'-ye's to deliver; the constant Business of Men of my Cloth, you know.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha! yonder comes my Father-in-law that is to be. I must avoid him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: And the Widow's Lord with him. Aside. Pray who is the Gentleman with him, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: His Name is Bite, to the best of my Memory. He belongs to a Pharoah-Table, I us'd to see him Tally sometimes, that's all I know of him. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I'm glad I know so much of him. Bite, Quotha! Egad, I'll take care he shan't Bite me of the Widow. —Is this her Man of Quality?— Sam, go you home, and don't you be out of the way, if I shou'd want you. Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Egad, this Woman fatigues me more than a long March. But the Hopes of her Gold, like the Hopes of Plunder, give me fresh Courage for continuing the Siege.
sp.l: Still to Besiege, and Storm, the Soldier's Trade is,
In War, to carry Towns; — In Peace, the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: YOUR Story, Madam, I confess is moving; but I am more surpriz'd at Freeman's Insensibility, than at his Perjury. It is no wonder to find a Man false; but that he should be Blind to so much Beauty, is an Argument of Stupidity.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Not when he changes for Superiour Merit;
But if you love not the Dissembler;
Oh, give him back to my desiring Arms!
For we are fit Companions for each other.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: All I can, besure I'll do to serve thee.
Dear hast thou bought, the faithless, worthless Man

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Too late, I blame my credulous Nature.
Our Sex, like Roses blooming on the Tree,
Admir'd by ev'ry gazing Passenger:
The Flow'r once cropt, a while 'tis worn in Triumph;
Then thrown aside, to wither in Disgrace.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to give this Letter to Sir John, and pursue whatever he directs you. Depend upon any Thing in my Power to serve you, Madam; My Soul abhors this Treachery, and had he been as Dear to me, as his poor Injur'd Brother is, I would renounce him now, tho' Life went with him.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: My Father! that's unlucky. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Pray, Daughter, what is this pretty Resolution of yours? Who wou'd you renounce?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: One whom you wou'd have me, Sir, if you but wish my Happiness; 'tis that Deceiver Freeman.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: How! Why, what has Sir John recover'd the Estate then? If so, Egad I shall renounce him too, Girl. —Ho'now, Who have we here? Some Letter-Carrier, ha? Pray, who let you in, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Justice.
Look on this Lady, Sir, with Eyes more human,
On her whom Freeman basely has betray'd,
Just in her rising Bloom and Pride of Youth.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Why, you'd make an excellent Actress; you Rant and Strut it well; but who is this Lady you are so tender of, pray?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: She's Freeman's Wife, by all the Ties of Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ties of Love—Hark ye! Has the Parson ty'd 'em? Love makes none but running Knots, and a Man may slip those at Pleasure; but the Parson's Noose is as sure as the Hangman's; nothing but the Grave unties it.—Now if you have him in that String, Madam, you are on the right side of the Hedge, and I must look out for another Son-in-law.—Otherwise, you must look sharp for another Husband — that's all.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: By my Country's Custom 'tis I claim him.
I can have no other Husband;
For all our Vows are Register'd in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Humph! that's a long way off, and very few Lawyers go that Circuit. I doubt you'll lose your Cause for want of Evidence too.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: No, Sir, she has a living Witness of his Guilt,
A Boy, the very Picture of the Villain.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: A Pledge of Love, and everlasting Faith.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Can you defend his Treachery, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Can you defend her Folly? Treachery Quotha! He's a Traytor who weakens his King, not he who adds to the Number of his Subjects.—You say, you claim him by your Country's Custom, pray what Country is that, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Holland, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Odso! Holland; why their High Mightinesses ought to settle a Pension upon you. I wish you much Joy of your Son, Madam. I warrant him a Hero, or a Politician. Ev'ry English-Man's Son, merrily begot, proves a Great Man. Fools and Cowards are the Product of our Wedding-Sheets. I wish he had laid such a Foundation in my Family, before the Lawfulness of the Pleasure spoils the Breed.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Are these fit Speeches for a Daughter's Ear?
And this the Language of a Vertuous Parent?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: The Vertue of a Parent consists in Interest and Cunning now-a-Days, as your Sex's Modesty does in Pride and Affectation.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Monstrous Precepts!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I suppose, Madam, you had nothing but Mr. Freeman's bare Word?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Words of the most Sacred Form! Vows of Eternal Faith! Eternal Constancy!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: But how the Devil cou'd you expect Peformance? Can any Man promise for Futurity? You should have got him into Bonds. Hereafter let me advise you, Do nothing till you have 'em under Black and White.—Then, if they fly the Parson, catch 'em with the Proctor.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Unmannerly Advice; but I was told before I came, what small Regard you paid to Justice. —It is in you, Madam, that all my Hopes are center'd.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Depend on me, in all I can.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No whispering in my House, no cabaling, no underhand Dealing.—Look ye, Madam, the Man's dispos'd of; but if you will let me know whereabouts your Fortune may be, I'll do my Endeavour to get you a Husband.— I will, Faith.

lg.l: Since Injur'd Vertue is become your Sport,
And you, instead of pitying, mock my Sorrow,
I'll try all Arts that may his Soul subdue;
But if I fail his Passion to renew,
The Traytor dies, to be reveng'd on you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why will you raise her Indignation thus?
Do you not dread the Consequence?
Base as he is, will you not guard his Life?
Oh! call her back, and calm her Passion;
If you prevent not, you encourage Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No, no, the Threats of your Sex, like Courtiers Promises, vanish into nothing. Passion has left the weeping Corner, and now it blusters like the North Wind, that's all. I wonder who let this Woman in. I shall examine that Point with my Servants.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Are you a Man yet void of all Humanity?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip,
sp.p: If your Mother were alive, she'd tell you: How dare you call me Father, and question my Manhood? What would you make your Mother, Hussey? ha!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh do not name my Mother! Were she alive, you would not treat me thus. Remember your Promise to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: But when I made that Promise, he was Heir Apparent to Four Thousand Pounds a Year, and Nobody dreamt of his being Disinherited. — Zounds, do you think I'll throw away my Money upon your Inclination, Mistress? No, mark me, Were thy Mother here in all her Bloom of Beauty; here, here, upon her Knees before me, I wou'd not break my Word to Freeman; that is to say, whilst he is Master of his Father's Estate; therefore urge me no more, but prepare to be his Wife to morrow. D'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: To morrow! short Warning! yet short as 'tis, I shall have time for Resolution; and you shall find it, Father, as Unalterable as your own.
sp.l: If where I've fix'd my Love, I must not Wed,
I'll choose a Coffin for my Bridal Bed.

div.head: SCENE Watchit's House.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p:
SINCE my Husband resolves to immure me, I'm glad my Jayl is so luckily situated. Here I may hope for some Consolation; The agreeable Address of Freeman charms me; my Husband's Jealousy provokes me; and the Conveniency of that dear Door, is so irresistable, that if I should not be able to withstand Temptation, my Husband may take it for his Pains: Besides, as the Poet says,
One had as good commit the Fau't,
As always to be Guilty thought.
There's some Pleasure in reflecting upon past Delights; and Confinement will sit more easy, when one knows one deserves it; but to be shut up for nothing, is not to be borne.
Well, Lucy: Have you given the Signal?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: There was no need of a Signal, Madam: I found Mr. Freeman in my Chamber, waiting the happy Minute. Oh! were these Men but half so eager after Possession! — But then, the Park, the Play, a Bottle; nay, an Afternoon's Nap, shall have important Business in't.—But here he is, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Ned Freeman, and runs into her Arms.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
My Charmer! I have stood Centinel at my Window these Two Hours, to watch your old Jaylor
out; and the Moment I saw him hobble over the Channel, I flew to the kind Door, impatient to be let into Paradise.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wat.
sp.p: The impatient'st Lover, at the Beginning of an Amour, commonly proves the most indolent after Possession, they say.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: That, Madam, in a great measure, depends upon the Wit and Temper of the Lady; After Enjoyment, Love grows nice; Beauty kindles up the Flame: But there is more required to keep that Flame alive: But you may boast your Sex's whole Perfection: He who puts on your Chains, must be your Slave for Ever. Where Souls sympathize, the Bodies fear no Separation. When I but kiss thee [Embracing her] my Heart flutters at my Lips, as if 'twould tell thee every Thought within.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Bless me! what do you mean? I doubt you have naughty Thoughts! —Give us the Cards.— Come, I must have my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: That you shall, with all my Soul, instantly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Be quiet then, and take the Cards.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: The Cards! No, no, my Angel, I shall beat you at Cards; there is a sweeter Game for your Revenge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pish! what Game? — Lud! — you smother one. Suppose any of the Servants should be upon the Stairs? — Lucy!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [aside.] Humph! I understand her. I'll take Care of that, Madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You see, my Life, Mrs. Lucy knows her Business: Why should we neglect ours?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Business! What Business? Oh Lud! what would you have me do? Struggling a little.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Make me the happiest of Mankind. A thousand Loves are dancing in your Eyes. Your balmy Lips and heaving Breasts invite me to the Banquet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Don't talk to me thus, you insinuating Devil, you! — Let me go! —Oh gad! I an't able to struggle any longer! —

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Why will you struggle at all? Why destroy that Pleasure which your Consent so infinitely would raise? Come, lead me to my Bliss, where, folded in each other's close Embraces, we'll bid Defiance to a Husband's Frown, and kiss, and laugh at all his jealous Folly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh gad! — Oh, oh Lud! — I have not Breath to answer — Oh, oh! I must not — dare not —will not —Oh Lud! —I have such a Swimming in my Head! — Let me go! — Tho' if you do, I am sure I shall fall down.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Oh my yielding Dear! — Where the Duce shall I find the Bed Chamber?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: 'Tis the next Room. — Ha! What have I said? Did you name the Bed-Chamber? Oh Gad! I won't go into the Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No, no, no, my Dear, I would not offer to injure your Modesty with such a Thought for the World. Go into the Bed-chamber! No, no, I'll carry thee thither. Takes her in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Nay, how can you be so rude? Lord, whither are you going? I swear I have a good Mind to cry out. Lucy shrieks without.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha! What Shriek is that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: 'Tis Lucy's Voice! Set me down, set me down! my Husband is most certainly return'd. What shall I do? O Invention! O Invention! Pauses.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Pox take him for an unmannerly Churl, to make a Gentleman rise from Table before he has tasted the first Dish; and with such an Appetite too!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh gad! don't loiter here; but fly, fly, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But whither, Madam? Whither? Which way can I get up Stairs, without meeting him full in the Teeth? Except you have any back-way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I'll venture; (for it is impossible for him to get out.) Here, here, here, Sir, step behind this Screen, and stir not for your Life, 'till I give you Notice. Ned goes behind the Screen.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What the Devil did you shriek out for? To give Warning, Mrs. Scriech-Owl?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Warning! of what, I wonder? Who could you expect to catch, that you came creeping up in this Manner, to fright a-body out of one's Wits? You suffer nothing to come near my Lady but Flies, that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Throwing herself upon the Floor.] Oh, Misery! — Oh, oh, oh! —

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nothing but Flies! why Flies breed Maggots, Hussey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh undone! Undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Oh my poor Lady on the Floor! Help, Sir, help. — Where have you put the Gentleman, Madam?
Aside to Mrs. W.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Behind the Screen. [Aside.] Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Pud, What is the Matter, Pud?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I fear I have broke my Leg, Mumps.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Heaven forbid! —Though if she has, there will be one Advantage in't; she won't teize me to go abroad these two Months. [Aside.] —Let me see; where-abouts hast thou hurt thy pretty Leg?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Just in my Instep, Mumps! — Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Lucy! Where are you, Hussey! help me to set your Mistress in a Chair. How camest thou to fall, Pudsey? They lift her into a Chair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Why, hearing her shriek, I ran hastily to see what was the Matter; and my Heel happening to catch in my Hoop, down I came, with my Foot double under me. — Oh dear Mumps! you hurt me terribly! Pray lead me to my Bed, that I may lie down 'till a Surgeon can be sent for.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Peeping] Well propos'd!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, no, let me rub it a little; I don't find it is broke: One must not make Surgeon's Work of every little Accident. It is not broke, Pudsey, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wish your Neck had been broke, when you came Home. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: It may be sprain'd, perhaps. I have some Camphirated Spirits of Wine in the Corner-Cupboard, behind that Screen. I'll fetch it, and bathe it with some of that. It is exceeding good for a Sprain.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Peeping] So! I find a Law-suit commenced already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: If he comes near the Screen, I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What, in the Name of Jupiter, will become of the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh dear, dear, Mumps! do not leave me. Give Lucy the Key; let her fetch it. Catches hold of him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, give me the Key; and do you keep rubbing, that the Blood may circulate.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Peeping] Well said, Mrs. Abigail.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Ay, do, dear Mumpsy! Methinks there's a kind of Ease whilst you are rubbing it. — Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: [rising] No, no, she can't find it; she'll fling down some of the Bottles; that's all the Good she'll do.

sp.speaker: Mrs W.
sp.p: Oh, I shall swoon, if you stir, Mumps! — I shall, I shall! Catches hold of him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Well, well! I won't go! — You Women are so impatient! Here, Lucy, take the Key. It is in a Crystal Bottle. Don't you do Mischief now, amongst the rest of the Spirits.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Peeping] I wish I were a Spirit to go out unseen. —

div.stage: Mrs. Watchit beckons Ned to go off, whilst old Watchit is rubbing her Foot.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She beckons you to go out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I understand her. But if the old Fellow should look up!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
No, no, never fear; I'll help to screen you from his Sight. [Runs and flaps herself down by
Watchit] Here, here, Sir, here's the Bottle. I'm sure 'tis the right.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What is the Devil in the Wench! have you a a Mind to lame me, Hussey? Why don't you pull out the Cork?

div.stage: Ned advances, but as Watchit looks up, retires.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Hang the Cork. — Rub, rub, rub, dear Mumps.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Beckons Ned] Now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What's now, now! ha!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why, now the Cork's out! Lord, you don't mind my Mistress's Foot?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Aside.] Ah! he will catch him, that's certain. — I have such a Terror upon me, that I'm disarm'd of all Excuses.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Where lies thy Pain, Pud?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Just where you are.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That I dare swear [Aside.] — Bless me, Sir, how my Lady's Ancle swells?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Your Nose swells, don't it? What do you fright your Mistress for, Hussey? I see no Swelling.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I dont know how he should. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Aside.] She might have laid a Foundation for a Swelling, if you had been Civil enough to have stay'd away half an Hour longer.

div.stage: Advancing to the middle of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Come, try to stand upon't, Pudsey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Shrieking.] Ah! my dear, dear Life and Soul! I cannot bear it!

div.stage: As Watchit is raising her up, she throws her Arms about his Neck to prevent his seeing Ned.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: [Struggling] What, will you smother me? How now! Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: So! he has me! —I admire you leave your Doors open, Sir, and not a Servant in the Way to take a Message.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
Had you any to send up, Sir? I don't like a Man that comes up to my Nose; then tells me, I admire
you leave your Doors open. — Zounds, was there not a Knocker to the Door?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I did knock, Sir; but my Business would not give me leave to wait.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Business▪ —What, to rob my House? or lie with my Wife, I warrant, had I been out of the Way. [Aside] —I pray you, sweet Sir, What may your hasty Business be?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What, in the Name of Jupiter, shall I pretend? Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Aside to Lucy] Oh Lud! what Tale can he invent? I tremble every Joynt of me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Aside to Mrs. W.] If he proves of the true Irish Breed, all may go well yet.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, you have forgot your Business. — A clean-limb'd young Rascal, this; — and has a damn'd Cuckold-making Air: Zounds, how my Wife eyes him! Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I have it; Impudence protect me [Aside.] The Affair I come upon, Sir, requires your private Ear.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sir, I keep my private Ears, for my publick Friends. I have survey'd you round, and round; and, to be plain, I don't like your Phiz, and, may be, I shall like your Business worse. Therefore, will hear, whether it be worth going out of the Room for or not.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I can easily pardon your Dislike to my Face; but I must insist upon speaking with you alone.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I insist upon your speaking here, Sir —The Dog will cut my Throat, perhaps. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I'm in pain for the Event. Aside to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
The Gentleman promises well; Have Courage, Madam.
Aside to Mrs. W.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But your Reputation is concern'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: My Reputation does not depend upon your Tongue, Sir; and I'll not stir a Foot.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But have you no Regard to your Lady, Sir? for I perceive this is your Wife.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And what of that, Sir? What have you to say against my Wife? Out with it.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I have nothing to say, Sir, against your Wife.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'S'death, Sir! What is your Business? What have you to say? Speak, Sir; —Or, or —

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Nay! if I must speak here! Then know, Sir, I am employed by Sir Andrew Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Gudgeon! I doubt, Friend, you have mistaken your Fish; for I know no Man of that Name.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sir, a Word. [Speaks in his Ear] You know his Wife, I suppose, if you don't know him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Wife! what Wife? Ad's Heart! speak out, and keep farther off. — This Dog's a Pick-pocket, for aught I know. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Why then, I must tell you, Sir, that Sir Andrew will have Satisfaction, before he and you have done.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Satisfaction for what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: For lying with his Wife, Sir, since you will have it out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Adultery! Very fine, truly!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Bless me! who could have thought, that my Lady had not been sufficient for you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Zounds! what do you mean, Sir? Do you think to make a Gudgeon of me?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Nor you must not think to make a Cuckold of Sir Andrew, without making him Satisfaction, Sir. I don't value your high Words, nor your big Looks. I am not to be frighted out of my Business, Sir. I am a Proctor in the Bishop's Court, and employ'd by Sir Andrew, to exhibit a Libel against you for Incontinency.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Oh Lord! oh Lord! I incontinent! I'll be judg'd by my own Wife. —Pud! —come hither, Pud —speak the Truth, and no more but the Truth, —Didst thou ever find me a Man given that way?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p:
I wonder you have the Assurance to look me in the Face! I find your Suspicions of my Vertue, proceeded from the Weakness of your own —Ungrateful
Man! Have I kiss'd and hugg'd you in my Arms for this? Bursts seemingly into Tears.

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.p: Ah! did ever I think this of you, Sir? You, who have such a tender, fond, loving, lovely Wife of your own! I can't help weeping to see my poor Lady so ill-treated.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Was ever innocent Man thus baited?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Ah, Mumps! I never thought you were such a Hypocrite. — How often have you told me, what a crying Sin Adultery is! And —

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: This must be a Trick to abuse me! —Get out of my House, Sir. Zounds, get out of my House!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Get out of your House! Get ready your Bail, Sir. The Allegations against you are so plain, and positive, you'll scarce have any Room for an Evasive Answer, or to cross-examine the Witnesses upon New Interrogatories, Sir, —Mind that.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You and your Interrogatories had best march off, Sir, without any more to do, or —

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: If I might advise you, make up this Matter, and don't expose yourself.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Why Pud! do you think I am guilty, Pud? Oh Lud! oh Lud! oh Lud!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Why, can you have the Assurance to deny it, after what the Gentleman has said?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: His denying it, Madam, will signify nothing; we have unquestionable Proofs; Causes of this Nature never come into our Court without Demonstration.— He must undergo the Sentence usual in these Cases. — Which is, To stand in a White-Sheet, and humbly confess his Faults before the Congregation. Besides which, [Turning to Him.] you will be compelled to pay Costs and Damages.— And if you are found Guilty of Contumacy, as your present Behaviour seems to promise, we shall get you Excommunicated.

sp.speaker: Mrs W
sp.p: Excellent Fellow! Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Upon which comes out the Writ Excommunicato Capiendi: That, whips you up in an Instant;
carries you to the next Jayl, and delivers you into Salvo Custodio; without Bail, or Mainprize.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What, hoa! within there? Where are all my Rascals? Hussey, go look 'em, [pushes Lucy] and bid 'em call a Constable. I'll Bail and Mainprize you, I warrant you, Sirrah: Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'll not stir a Step: You wicked Man, you! —

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: A Constable!—that may not be so well. Aside. I'm not afraid of a Constable, Sir. Send for him, and welcome; but the least Noise you make in this Affair, the better, Sir Nicholas!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Sir Nicholas! here must be some Mistake in this; my Husband's Name is not Nicholas, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What say you, Madam? Is not this Sir Nicholas Widgeon?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, nor Woodcock neither, as you shall find, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Bless me! What have I been saying all this while? I ask your Pardon, Sir, with all my Heart. How the Vengeance cou'd I make such a Blunder? I was directed next Door to the Sun.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If I mistake not, Sir Nicholas lives at the next House but one. I am glad to find it a Mistake, Sir, and that you are not guilty of wronging so good a Woman, as my Lady is.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: It is a very pretty Mistake, tho', to come into a Man's House, and abuse, and threaten him with White-Sheets, Penance, and the Devil; and then, I ask your Pardon, Sir. A Pox on you and your Pardon too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Nay, you have Reason to be angry, I own, Sir—and I wish I knew how to make you some Satisfaction.—Madam, Can you forgive me? Upon Honour, I'm in such Confusion!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I believe him. [Aside.] The Pleasure of finding my Husband innocent, inclines me the more easily to pardon your Mistake, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I protest, Sir, I am very much out of Countenance!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I wish you were out of my House, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: If you shou'd ever have any Business in Doctors Commons, Sir, I assure you, no Body shall be —

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir, that nothing can oblige me more, than to see your Backside; and so, sweet Mr. Proctor, with your Excommunicato Capiendi, I am your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Sir, I am yours intirely. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wat.
sp.p: Charming Fellow! Aside.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Pox take him, he has given me the Palpitation of the Heart, which I shan't get rid of these two Hours.—Why, what a multitude of Troubles will this poor Sir Nicholas be in now? His Sweet Meat will have Sowre Sauce.— Odd, there's a pretty Penny to be made of these Cuckold-making Dogs▪ if one could but catch 'em Napping. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Aside.] Well, this is a Jewel of a Man, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, this Man has a Genius, and deserves a Woman. Aside to her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I can't get this Fellow's Mistake out of my Head; it is a cursed odd one, methinks. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: How does your Foot do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pretty well, I think, Lucy: Your Hand has done me exceeding Service, Mumps.—

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Chick, ev'ry one don't know the Virtue of a warm Hand.—I don't like this sudden Cure.—To roar out, but now when I touch'd it; and now to walk about, as if nothing ail'd her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If you were a Surgeon, Sir, and cou'd effect Cures so soon, you'd grow Rich apace.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: [Aside.] I wish you, and your Mistress, have not all your — I might not always be so lucky.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: To prevent your being made a Cuckold, I grant you. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I took this, just in the Nick.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Or she had Nick'd you. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That is to say, just as 'twas done.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, before it was done; to my Lady's Sorrow. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Well, Mumps! I must remind you of your Promise: I must go out to Day.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Fy, fy, you would not walk upon your Foot so soon; would you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pho! I tell you my Foot is well: Besides, I can take a Chair.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Prithee, what Business hast thou abroad, Wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Why, I want to go to Chapel, in the first Place.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: The Saints will hear you as well, from your Closet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I can't Pray in my Closet.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nor any where else, I believe. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Besides, here are Priests in London.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Ay! Enough to corrupt the whole Nation.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And it is a mortal Sin not to Confess, when 'tis in one's Power to do it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Pray, what Sins have you committed, that you are in such haste to unburthen?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You are not qualify'd to know.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Well, since your Conscience accuses you, you shall have a Priest. I'll send to the What-d'ye-call-'em Ambassador's, for one of his; who shall take your Confession in your Closet; but I'll stand at the Door: For I would not trust one of these Pardon-selling Rogues: They have such convincing Arguments for Cuckoldom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Why, do you think, Sir, that I'll be shut up thus, for ever?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay, if you begin to exalt your Voice, then I must tell you, It is my Pleasure to have it so. Let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: No, that will not suffice; for it's against my Inclination.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Which is not to be suffic'd? for you are never satisfy'd with gadding; if we Husbands shou'd always follow our Wives Inclinations, we should be in a fine Condition.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am sure you have all Conditions, but good ones. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Is this your Matrimonial Vow! to imprison me; You that wou'd Cherish, Love, and Worship me!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: So I do, don't I, my dear Flesh and Blood? Thou are my Goddess, and I adore Thee; and cannot suffer Thee out of my Sight.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If you Two are One Flesh, how come you to have such different Minds, pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Because the Mind has nothing to do with the Flesh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: That's your Mistake, Sir; the Body is govern'd by the Mind. So much Philosophy I know.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I believe you understand Natural Philosophy very well, Wife: I doubt the Flesh has got the better of the Spirit in you.—Look ye, Madam! Ev'ry Man's Wife is his Vineyard; you are mine, therefore I Wall you in. Ads-budikins, ne'er a Coxcomb in the Kingdom, shall plant so much as a Primrose in my Ground.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I am sure, your Management will produce nothing but Thorns.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay, ev'ry Wife is a Thorn in her Husband's Side; Your whole Sex is a kind of Sweet-Bryer, and he who meddles with it, is sure to prick his Fingers.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That is, when you handle us too roughly.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You are a kind of Rue; neither good for Smell nor Taste.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But very wholesome, Wife.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Ay, so they say of all Bitters; yet I wou'd not be oblig'd to feed upon Gentian, and Wormwood.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, you like Sweet-Meats better.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Confinement wou'd Cloy me with Them too.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Or you are no Woman.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: But what do's this signify to our Marriage-Articles? You know the Forfeiture, if you deny me Ghostly Aid.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: A Thousand Pounds.—You bit me there.— Have a care I don't bite you again. [Aside.] — Well, well, you shall have this Ghostly Aid —But do you consider, you never had the Small-Pox, and it never was so Mortal as now; therefore it is not convenient you shou'd go Abroad; indeed it is not, Pudsey. —'Tis out of pure Love to thee, Faith, my Dear; for the Small-Pox wou'd spoil that pretty Face: It wou'd truly, Pud: Prithee now, believe thine own Mumps.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Away!—I hate your Wheedling. Those who languish under the Plague, need not fear the Small-Pox.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Humph! Say you so? I shall indeed be a Plague to you, if I catch you tardy, Gentlewoman. Odd, I can't put this Foot of hers out of my Head; it looks like an Excuse to conceal some secret Failing, and puts me in mind of a youthful Stratagem of my own. Having been a little Familiar with one of my Mother's Maids, and like to have been caught, I cut my Finger, and pretended I came for a Rag to bind it up.—This Fellow with his Excommunicato Capiendi, too, may have more in't than I can see through: I resolve to examine my Servants, if ever they saw him before; but in Personating this Priest, I shall know all.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Shall you so?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: I have bespoke a Disguise; and am resolv'd to take her Confession my self.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed! — My Lady shall know your Contrivance; and if she does not fit you for your Curiosity, I am mistaken, old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: If she has Cuckolded me, tho' but in Thought, I will enjoin her such a Penance!
sp.l: 'Ounds! I'll so swinge, so mortify the Jade,
That she shall ne'er forget my Ghostly Aid.

div.head: SCENE, Widow Headless's House. She Wiping down the Dust with her Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: JUDITH! What hast thou been doing all this Morning, that my Dressing-Room is in this Pickle?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Pickle!

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Ay, Pickle, Sauce-box; Why dost thou Eccho me?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Eccho you!

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Again! — Indeed I shall slap your Chaps, if you don't learn to leave off repeating my Words after me.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: After you! —Marry, I —

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: [Gives her a Box o' the Ear] You will do it then.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Will do what? Chem zhour, chem can do nothing to please you! Chem clean'd it as it hod bin vor min Life; zo I dud.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Life! what is thy Life, Muck-worm, to a clean Room? Dost thou imagine Rooms lie thus at Court? Ha, Slattern?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: They can't lie better, I think.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Think! Why dost thou think, Animal? What hast thou to do with Thought? Mind thy own Business, and never puzzle thy Noddle with Thought.
Bless me! my Lord, and Sir Philip! —I am asham'd to be caught in this Disorder!

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: My Lord and I have been fetching a Walk, and I could not persuade his Lordship to pass by your Door, Cousin, without calling. You are his North, and he is embark'd in the Cock-boat of Love, and is constantly pointing this way.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: You are very pleasant this Morning, Sir Philip. But. —

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I ask your Pardon, Madam; but finding your Door open, and no-body in the way, the Knight undertook to be Master of the Ceremonies, as well as to answer the Reproaches I might reasonably expect from you, for this Liberty —

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Oh, good my Lord, no Apology! That ought to be done by me for the Disorder your Lordship finds me in. —Go, Beesom, and look for your Fellow-Puzzles, and ask 'em, Why they leave my Doors open? I shall be robb'd one of these Days. — Sure, never any-body was so fatigu'd with Servants as I am. Did you ever visit a Lady in a Stable before, my Lord? Oh gad! I shall be stuck, mir'd, laid fast, and forc'd to be dug out like a Potatoe.

div.stage: Holds up her Coats, and walks cautiously.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: A Stable, Madam! I protest I think your House is as much in Order, as any Lady's in London.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, there are few of the Quality such Housewives, as my Cousin. If it be your Lordship's good Fortune to marry her, she'll set the Ladies at Court a Pattern.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Fy, Sir Philip! This to my Face! it looks like Flattery.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: What would be Flattery to another, is but doing you Justice, Madam. —

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Women have no Defence against the fine Things you well-bred Men say. To raise our Vanity, and make us have a good Opinion of ourselves, you are sure, is one way to be well in our Esteem.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I should think myself the happiest Man living, if I cou'd perceive I had the least Share in yours, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: His Lordship complains, Cousin, that you are Inexorable. — Hark ye, one Word with you. —Don't over-stand your Market. A Man of Quality is not to be caught every Day.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Listening] There's an old Rogue, now!

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me marry a Man as soon as he asks me the Question, Sir Philip? I think, to have an Amour with a Person of Rank known and talk'd of, is one of the greatest Inducements to Matrimony; especially if it gives the rest of my Sex Pain.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside] Right Woman, on my Conscience!

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: My Lord! won't your Lordship please to rest yourself?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: My Rest depends upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside] Who shall never be a Resting-place for you to Tally on.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I'm certain, 'tis not in my Power to give your Lordship Pain.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So —Another Trap! but I'll spoil the Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: More than your whole Sex.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Your Lordship will make me vain.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: If there could be any Addition to the Vanity that thou hast already. Aside.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Oh, Jeffery! —Well, have you delivered all my Messages?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Be Mess, I think so.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Ha! Looking wistfully at him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: How many dud you gi me, Forsooth?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Madam, —Oh the Clodhopper! Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Mrs. What-ni-cull-um, at the Hog's-Head, was gone out, chu'd seem.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Madam! Blockhead.

div.stage: Gives him a Box on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! this is like to be a diverting Scene.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: How often must I instruct you to behave your self before Company? Will you never learn Manners, Booby?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, I shan't, an yow go on at thick same slip-slap Rate. —Nouns, an thick be London-Breeding, send me into the Country agen, I say.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: If I were thy Lady, Fellow, thou should'st have thy Wish.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Say yow so? Ay! but Curst Cows have short Horns, we say in our Country▪ — I shall never be your Servant, I hope!

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: How now, Sause-box! do you know who you talk to?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Yes, I do —better than you think for, me-hap.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: [Aside] How's that? 'S Death, if this Bumkinly Dog should know me, he'll spoil all.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I have a good Mind, Sirrah, to dash your Teeth down your Throat.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So yow ma' an you wol. What does he meddle wi' me for, then? I dud not meddle wi' him; dud I?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: You'll have your Bones broke in London, Sirrah. I admire my Lord does not Cane you, Scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: His being this Lady's Servant protects him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, it is that protects yow; for an I had yow in my Country —

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: This Fellow and I must have a little Confabulation. I must stop his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sirrah, no more of your Impudence; but give me an Account of the Business I sent you about. How does Lady Lucy, Lady Lock-up, Lady Love-it, Lady Set-up, Lady Comely, Lady Revel, Lady Ramble, Mrs. Prim, Mrs. Prude, Mrs. Costly, and Mrs. Travel?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nowns! her Tongue runs like the Mill at Vather's Orchard-End, that scares Crows fro' the Cherry-Tree.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Does it so, Sirrah?

div.stage: Runs to beat him, but Tally steps in between.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Hold, hold, dear Madam: Let me intercede for Mr. Jeffery this once.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] How civil the Dog is!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your Lordship commands me. Well, Mrs. Fisk-out, at the Boar's-Head, which you call the Hog's-Head, Clumsy! was gone out, you say?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So she was.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: [Aside to Fainwell.] Madam! —Jeffery— Madam—You forget.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Hoa! you have squeez'd out Madam at last.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Squeez'd —Od! would I had the squeezing of yow.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: How, Sirrah, you squeeze me! —My Lord! Sir Philip! Did you ever hear such a Varlet!

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: You see, Madam, your Beauty reaches all Degrees. He speaks his Heart, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: You have him as you breed him.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p:
Oh, that's barbarous, Sir Philip. You don't know the Pains I take with my Clodpated Family. —Well!
Looking at Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
Yes, they are well, Madam. —An hope yow are well, Madam —And they'll all —or some of them, come to see yow, Madam. —So they gi' their Loves — Loves? No, no —So they gi' their Service to yow, Madam —An, an, an, an,
So that's all, Madam. —There's Madam enough for yow now, I think, if yow know when you have enough.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Now Jeffery has done it. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I have been teaching him the distinguishing Rap, these three Days; and yet, I warrant, he'll knock with the sneaking Air of a Taylor. Let's hear how you perform? He knocks aukwardly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Execrable! —Didn't I tell you so? —There, Blockhead. — She thunders at the Door.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: By'r Lady! that's enough to fright all the Dogs in Town.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In the Opinion of such a Puppy as you are — Go, bid the Cook set on the Tea-kettle, and cut some Bread and Butter —But, d'ye hear? don't you bring it dangling in your Fist, as you did Yesterday, Sloven—If you do, I shall throw it at your Head, Sir. Remember to bring me nothing without a Plate: D'ye hear? —You han't Breakfasted, I hope, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Yes, long since.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: So have I, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Jeffery's talking of Dogs, puts me in mind of a Message from my Daughter. She bid me tell you, she expects a Puppy: Has your Bitch litter'd yet, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not yet, Sir Philip. You never saw a poor Creature so big in your Life. Jeffery fetch Misha hither [Fainwell going] — Hark-ye! Hark-ye! — Come back. [He runs up to her Nose.] What! — will you run your Nose into my Mouth? Where are your Manners, when you leave the Room? —Still that Scrape? I thought I had shew'd you to bend your Body only, and keep your Feet upon the Ground.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: By'r Lady, you'll make an ambling Nag o' me by-and-by. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p:
[Aside.] Nothing but thy Twenty thousand Pounds could make Amends for thy Impertinence.
—I admire you give your-self the Trouble of Country-Servants, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I would not keep a Town-Servant, my Lord, if they would live with me for nothing. Their whole Attention is Drunkenness and Pride. The dirtiest Trollup in the Town must have her Top-knot and Tickin-shoes. This City spoils all Servants. I took a Welsh Runt last Spring, whose Generation scarce ever knew the Use of Stockens: And —will you believe me, my Lord? She had not liv'd with me Three Weeks, before she sew'd Three Penny-Canes round the Bottom of her Shift, instead of a Hoop-Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: That was something better than a Wench at my House, who dis-rob'd a Barrel, and let all the Ale about the Cellar. One of the Ends of the Hoop working out, discover'd the Trick, and at the same time flung down a Side-Board of Glasses.—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ay, they do more Mischief than their Necks are worth. If the Parliament don't lay a Tax upon their Pride, there will be no living. I wish your Lordship would take it into Consideration.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well! —Where's Misha?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: By Mess, I can't bring her; not I.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How so? Is she so heavy?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, she's not so heavy: But I can't make her lie upon a Plate, for the Blood of me, so I can't.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Ridiculous enough! — Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A Plate, Blockhead! a Plate! Did you ever see a Dog brought on a Plate, Clodhopper? Did you?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Pure Innocence, faith!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, how do I know your London Vashons? —You bad me but now, I'm zure, to bring you nought without a Plate; so you dud.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What! —Living Things! —Ha, Did I say Living Things?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Living Things! 'S'Blead, the Devil would not live wi'yow —The Cobler wants Six-pence for mending your Clogs, Judith bod me tell yow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: These Wretches will distract me! —Is that a Message to be delivered to me in Publick? Ha, Thickscull? —But since you had no more Wit, let me see what he has done for the Money. — My Lord, youll excuse this Piece of Oeconomy. —

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Oh! Madam —

div.stage: Fainwell Re-enters, with the Clogs on a Plate.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Did you ever see the Fellow of him, Sir Philip? I protest he puts me into an Agony! Why, you Thickscull'd Rascal! — You unthinking Dolt! — You senseless ideot! — Was ever a Pair of dirty Clogs brought upon a Plate, Sirrah? —Ha? —Was there? —Was there? —Was there? —Hedge Hog?

div.stage: Follows him about and beats him, Sir Philip interposing.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: What d'ye strick me vor! —The Clogs ar'nt Living Things too, are they? —By the Mess, Ill take the Law of you, so I will, an yow thrash me about at thick same Rate. S'Blead, an yow were a Man, I'd dress your Jacket for yow.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil
sp.p: Fy, fy, Cousin, this is not like a fine Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That's your Mistake, Sir Philip; My Lady Flippant beats her whole Family, from her Husband to her Coachman.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: [Aside] I shall teach you better Manners, if once I get you.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] O Money! Money! what a Charm hast Thou?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Out of my Sight, Sirrah! —

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
Who the Murrain, cares to stay in it I wonder? Ah! Jeffery! Jeffery! thou art right enough
serv'd! —Why didst thou leave thy Sweetheart, Cicely, to pine away like a Goose in a Penn?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Why then you are False-hearted, Jeffery?

sp.speaker: Fain
sp.p: I have been Sir; with Shame I confess it, or I had ne'er come under Mistress's Clutches. —But,
sp.l: May all false-hearted Men my Fortune have,
And who slights Woman, be a Woman's Slave!
sp.p: I've somewhat to say to you, my Lord, when Time shall serve.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p:
I'll meet you in Covent-Garden Piazza, in Half an Hour.
Aside to Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Here's the Knight in Black to speak wi' yow. — Sir, Sir Freeman, I think you call him.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Sir John Freeman, you mean —Shew him up.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Hold, hold, let me begone first. I have some Reasons why I don't care to see him. —I had some Business with you, Cousin; but I'll send to you. —Will you walk, my Lord? Or shall I leave your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I'll wait on you, Sir Philip. —I take an unwilling Leave, Madam: But it may not be convenient to press upon your Business. —I long to know what this Fellow has to say to me [Aside.] —Your most obedient humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am your Lordship's —

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I ask you Pardon, Madam; I fear my Visit has robb'd you of better Company.

sp.speaker: Wid.
