sp.p: Not at all, Sir John: Your Father-in-Law, that was to have been, is just gone out; He seem'd unwilling to meet you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well he might, after his perfidious Usage.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But is your Brother really to marry my Cousin Olivia?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I have Reason to fear it; but hope he will be disappointed. I receiv'd Instructions from Olivia to wait on you, Madam, to ask a Favour of you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: She may command every thing in my Power, Sir John. What is it?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That you would give a Lady Entertainment in that Appartment which opens into the Backstreet.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, is it the Dutch Lady, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The same, Madam,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: She's welcome. May her coming prove propitious!

sp.speaker: Judith.
sp.p: Here's one Mr. Freeman, to wait on you, he says.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Brother! What can he want? Does he use to visit you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He never was here in his Life! I can't imagine his Business! —Would you see him?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, yes; but not a Word of the Business I came about.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You don't think me so indiscreet, I hope: Shew him up, Judith.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant. Ha! Brother! I'm glad to find you in such good Company. My Brother Jack's a pretty Fellow, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So he is indeed, Sir. He wants nothing but a Wife, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Aside.] Brother, I hope you conceive a Widow, when she makes such Wishes in your Favour. —She has Twenty thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What then, Sir? Why then He who marries her, will be worth Twenty Thousand Pounds —That's all!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I would advise You to marry her your self.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; but I'm provided.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Why then I wish you Joy, Brother, if you are sure of it. — Madam, I have a Message to you from Sir Philip Money-Love, who intended to have delivered it to you himself; but Company coming in, and being to meet a Lawyer at the Rummer, where I now left him, he was oblig'd to leave your Ladyship without telling you, that he came to know your Resolution about a Piece of Land that he mentioned to you some time ago. He would gladly buy it, or exchange with you for another; because that Ground is contiguous to some Part of his Estate, which he is about to settle upon his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let my Cousin know, that I gave my Lawyer Orders to treat with him about that Matter.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Where does your Lawyer live, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: At Number [2] in the King's-Bench Walks in the Temple. Sir Philip knows him.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Very well, Madam. — Brother, where shall I see you in the Evening?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am ingaged this Evening.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You'll make one in a Country Dance to Morrow, I hope? For that is to be my Wedding-day —

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope to baulk you yet. [Aside.] — I can promise nothing for Futurity, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Humph! You can't! — what you please, Sir. —Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How he triumphs!—How can you bear the Airs he gives himself, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To do him Justice, Madam, I believe he knows nothing of my Pretensions to Olivia. He was Travelling, when first I made my Addresses; and since his Return, we have not been so well with one another, to communicate Things of this Nature.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I ask your Pardon, Sir John, for keeping you standing. Won't you please to sit, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Excuse me, dear Madam; I intend to take this Opportunity to see Olivia, whilst her Jaylor's abroad, let the Consequence be what it will; and let her know, how much we are oblig'd to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My good Wishes attend you both, Sir John.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Piazza in Covent-Garden.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: HA! not here! Sure he do's not suspect me; and apprehend a Duel might ensue; All my Measures are broke, if he should. — Ho! here he comes.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: What can this Fellow have to say to me, I wonder? If he has discover'd me, he wants a Bribe. But I hope it is not so: for I shou'd be loth to have a Secret of this Nature lie in the Breast of such a Blunderer. [Aside.] — Mr. Jeffery! I protest I did not see you.— Well, what can I serve you in?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: In nought, that I know of, Zir; but me-haps, I may zerve yow in zomewhat, Zir,—my Lord, I wou'd zay. I beg yowr Pardon, Zir; we dan't zee zouch vine Voke in our Country every Day — zo that I hope yow won't be angry an I shou'd not hit upon your Worship's Name at every turn.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Angry! no, no, Mr. Jeffery, I hate Ceremony. —I find he does not know me; all's safe. [Aside.] If it were not necessary that we People of Quality shou'd be distinguish'd by the Titles and Degrees his Majesty has been pleas'd to Exalt us to; I wou'd not care if I were call'd plain Jack.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: If you were Exalted according to your Merit, you'd take your Degree at Tyburn. [Aside.] —Ay, ay, nothing but right, Zir, nothing but right.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: But which way am I to be oblig'd to you, Mr. Jeffery? I shan't prove ungrateful, I assure you.—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, as for that, d'ye zee—that's not the matter — I dan't want a Bribe. An tho' I be but a poor Fellow, and wears a tawdry Coat here, and am thumpt, and beaten about as you zee, I have an honest Heart in my Belly, and good Blood in me too, for aught I know: For yow mun understand, Vather was my Lord Firebrand's Gardiner, when I was got, chou'd zeem, and they zay, Mother was a deadly pretty Woman —

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: From whence you wou'd infer, that his Lordship might be your Father—Not unlikely; but go on—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I perceive yowr Lordship is a Suitor to my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I confess you are a Man of Penetration. I am indeed an Admirer of hers. —.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: The more's the pity. — I'm zorry for't.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Because, I'm zure she'll use yow like a Dog: I han't liv'd a Month wi' her, and to my knowledge she has made Fools of Three, or Four; main sightly Men, I promise yow.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: The Devil!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Starts.] Mercy o' me! Where, Zir? Dud yow zee any thing, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: No, no, I was only surpriz'd.—Cursedly Ignorant! Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Surpriz'd! be mess, the Devil wou'd surprize ony Man, an tho' he were the Parson o' the Parish.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: But has she had so many Lovers, say you?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Oh, a mort, Zir, a mort: But I can tell you one thing; She likes yow woundy well.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Ay! How dost thou know that, my Boy?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why, our Mary knows all her Heart, mun, an she tells me ev'ry thing. Odd, an yow knew as much as I cou'd tell yow, yowr Business might zoon be done, Zir; my Lord, I wou'd zay.—

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Ay! How, prithee?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: But won't yow be false-hearted now, and tell?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: What, against my self? No, no, there's no danger of that. Besides, I hope you don't think I wou'd be so ungenerous to you!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, as for that—I'm but a Servant; an one Place won't do, another woll, for that matter. Now what I am going to tell your Lordship, is none o' my Business, as one may zay; but it wou'd make a-body mad to zee a Woman flounce about House, like a Dog in a Ducking-Pond.—Now, Zir, an she had a Husband,— He, he, he, he! why me-haps,—he, he!—me-haps, I zay, he might vind her somewhat else to do, zometimes. Yow understand me, Zir?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Yes, yes, very well, Jeffery: If I had her once, I'd make her turn over a new Leaf.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
That I dare swear. [Aside.] Why, that was my very Thought now.—I wish yow had her, Sir; But you'll find it a knotty Piece of Work, let me tell yow but that; she deals as Scurvily with her Sweethearts, one way, as with her Servants another; and, I Cod, I ha' found her Fingers come slip-slap, this
a-way, and that a-way, like a Flail upon a Wheatsheaf.

div.stage: Flinging out his Arms, hits Tally a Slap o'the Face.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: A Pox of your Similies.— Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Od save me! Dud I hit yow, Zir?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Oh, no matter, Jeffery.—Go on—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I hope yowr Lordship's Worship will forgive me, Zir; I meant no harm, not I, Zir — But as I was zaying, — Mistress will give yow the Dog to hold, an yow do'no' give her somewhat.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Think'st thou so, Jeffery? Why what woud'st thou have me do?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Don't yow know that, without telling? There is zomewhat to be don, Zir, beside the Parson, or yow may dangle after her till Doom's Day, to no more purpose, than to winnow Corn without a Wind.— Her t'other Husband dud n't get her with Compliments, my Lord.—

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, no. He had been in Ireland, and knew better Things, Mun.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! Are We thought to have any particular Method to gain the Women, Jeffery? For I am of that Country, you must know.—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Are yow zo, my Lord: Nay, then, an all be true they zay o' yowr Country-Men, one need not tell yow which End to begin yowr Work at.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Ha! Is she to be won that way? I thank you for the Hint.— I find thou art a Lad of Parts; and when I am thy Master, I'll have thee taught to Shave, and make thee my Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I shall Shave you, I believe, before I have done with you.—With what an Assurance the Rogue talks. [Aside.] — I shall be main Thankful to yowr Lordship, an yow do, Zir; When wol yow come to our House agen?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: This Evening.—What is the best Time to find her alone?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Be mess, I known't that; but an yow find her alone, I'll take care Nobody shall disturb yow, an yow'll put it home to her.—

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Wo't thou! Egad, there's a Guinea for thee to drink my Health, then.— Never fear, I warrant thee, Boy, I'll have her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! How Generous the Rogue is: Well, I hope by this Stratagem, to give her a Disgust to his pretended Lordship; at least, I shall prove, if she has any thing valuable, besides her Money.

lg.l: To Talk of Vertue, is the Womens Pride;
But they give Proofs on't, who resist, when try'd.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: THIS is the House! Oh! for an Art to make my-self Invisible!

div.stage: Knocks, the Porter opens the Door.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Who would you speak with, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With your young Lady, Friend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: I wonder you'll be so troublesome, Sir. I told you before, I would not disobey my Orders. [He offers Money.] —I'll have none of your Money, Sir, —I'm not to be bribed to betray my Trust, I'd have you to know that.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Then you must be kick'd out of it, Sir.

div.stage: Pulls him out, gives him a Kick, enters, and shuts the Door.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Murder! Thieves! Murder! —This is a terrible Fellow. For my Part I'll never hinder him going in again. —And now he is in, I wish I had taken the Money. — He has shut the Door, and the Devil take them that open it, for Dick. Exit.

div.head: The SCENE changes to the Inside of the House.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: DIck! Will! John! What Noise of Murder is that? —Ah! Freeman! —

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Life! my Soul! Am I become so hateful to thee, that thou can'st not bear my Sight?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: How ill dost thou interpret my Surprize!
The unexpected Joy of seeing thee,
When no one Means supply'd me with a Hope,
To tell thee, —That to Morrow —

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thou art to be my Sister.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Blast the Name!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Perish my Brother first. —If thou art true. If thy Heart has not consented —

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: To him nor any, but thy-self.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Then not all the Brothers upon Earth shall take thee from me. Mrs. Headless readily complyed with your Request, and I have sent Louisa thither.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Alas! I fear that Lady's come too late.
The Time's so short, the Plot cannot succeed!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dost thou think so? Yet wilt thou stay, and sacrifice Thy-self and Me? Consent to fly with me, now, whilst Sir Philip is abroad.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But whither shall we fly?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Where Love directs us.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p:
I could, methinks, run any Risque with Thee; and thou perhaps, wouldst do the same with Me. Now in the Summer of our Love, little Cares would not offend us: But when the Glowing of the Passion's over, and pinching Cold of Winter follows, will
amorous Sighs supply the Want of Fire? Or kind Looks and Kisses keep off Hunger?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I think they would. But Love ne'er reasons thus, Olivia. I fear my Brother's Gawdy Train, has rais'd this Picture of Despair. He, he, has my Estate! Dare I, stript as I am, pretend to vye with him? I, who live upon his Bounty! —Bounty! damn the Word? Live on a younger Brother's Bounty, and see him wed the Woman I adore! — That Thought will hurry me to Madness!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You wrong my Love, and I should chide you for it, were our Condition happier. But to shew you I am a Lover-Errant, consider what Trade you can take up for a Livelihood. For my part, I can make Purses by Day, and sing Ballads by Night. Now, if you can grind Knives, or turn Tinker, I'm Yours. Slapping her Hand into his.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fortune can never cast us down so low. She owes thy Vertues more, methinks; This Dawn of Mirth, portends a joyful Day. Haste then my Fairest: Let us leave this Place, that we may gain Time, at least, to work Louisa's Purpose.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I'll only fetch a few Jewels; a sure Relief in Time of Need. [Goes to the Door, starts, and runs back.] Undone for ever! my Father's coming up!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Mischievous Accident! —What shall we do? Humph: [Pauses.] I have it. — Run you to your Chamber, my Angel, and when you hear a Noise, come forth, and wonder.

div.stage: Exit Olivia. Sir John lies down on a Couch, and pulls his Hat over his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Thus to be circled, thus to be embrac'd!
Oh! that I could hold thee Ever!

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha! What's this of embracing and holding for ever?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The Curtain's drawn, and see! She's here again!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: She's here! —Who's here? What is the Meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Jocasta! Ha! What fall'n asleep so soon?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Jocasta! Who's Jocasta? What in the Name of Vengeance, have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How fare's my Love?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Nay, who the Devil knows?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! Lightning blast me! Thunder rivet me for ever to Prometheus'-Rock, and Vultures gnaw out my incestuous Heart!

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: With all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: By all the Gods, it is my Mother Merope.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Merope! Who, in the Devil's Name, is she? —Ouns! Where are all my Rascals? Now will I be hang'd if here isn't a Pack of Strollers got into my House. Why, Rogues! Villains! where are you all? Who have you let in, Rascals?

sp.speaker: 1st Servant.
sp.p: We let in Nobody, Sir, not we.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Sword — A Dagger —Ha! who waits there?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Go look!

sp.speaker: 2d. Ser.
sp.p: Oh Lord! No-body, no-body at all, Sir. Fly, Master, fly! It is a Madman, to be sure!

sp.speaker: 1st Ser.
sp.p: Come away, Sir, come away? He'll certainly kill us. Exeunt Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The Devil go with you all —

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: [rising] Most triumphant Mischief! —
And now, whilst thus I stalk about the Room,
I challenge Fate to find another Wretch
Like Oedipus!

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oedipus! Just as I thought; Strollers! neither better nor worse. But how the Devil they got into my House, that's the Question?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Horror! Death! Confusion! Hell! and Furies!
Where am I?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Where you shan't be long, I promise you. —Ouns, 'tis that beggarly Badge of Quality, Sir John Freeman!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Oh, my Jocasta!
Let me hold Thee thus, thus to my Bosom,
Ages let me hold thee!

div.stage: Runs, and catches Sir Philip in his Arms▪

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Murder, Murder! 'S'Death! the Rogue will squeeze my Guts out.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Bless me! what is the matter, Sir? —Ha! Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: How you stare, Mistress! —You did not know that he was here! —No, not you —You was not to have been an Actor in this Droll, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Not I, indeed, Sir. I heard you cry out, and came to know the Cause.

sp.speaker: 1st Foot.
sp.p: What is the Matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Rascals, by-and-by.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are very welcome to stay and see the Play; but I must beg it may be on the other side the House. You'll crowd the Scenes so much, that the Actors can't enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The Actors! What Actors, Sir! —Ouns do you think I am to be droll'd out of my Daughter? —I thought I had forbid you my House?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pish, pish; you are out, Sir; confoundedly out —Hark-ye! Did you ever rehearse this Part, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: 'S'Death he'll make me Mad! —I shall make my Part good with you, I fancy. Fetch me a Constable.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Out again! —A Constable! Why, there is not such a Word in the whole Play. A Constable! why, they never heard of such a Thing in Thebes!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! don't you perceive his Brain is turn'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: His Brain! If he had had any Brains, he had not lost his Estate.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If I had had your Conscience, I should not.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: [pulling off his Hat.] Sir, will you be pleas'd to walk out of my House.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Look-ye, Sir, if you study your Part no better, I'll forfeit you, by Jupiter. —Hold, hold, hold! Ad's-Heart, Madam! You enter'd too soon —Oh think of something to defer this Marriage, tho' but for a Day.
Aside to Olivia.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: What a Vengeance are you whispering? ha?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, was that your Cue, now? If you don't mind your Cues, you can never make an Actor, Sir. —Here, Sir! here's a Woman for you, who never trod the Stage before, yet I'll be bold to say, That she'll surprize you. —Come! hold up your Head, my Dear —Mind your Business. —Enter boldly, and when you Exit, Exit—nimbly—Thus— Exit.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: I wish I could Exit with thee. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Stark Mad! This comes of sticking to Principles! I have known Principle starve Five hundred Fools; but never knew it feed one Wise Man yet.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: It will never starve you, I'm sure. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I'm glad he's gone —Come, come, dry up your Tears, and think of him no more. A Coach with Six before, and Six behind, with a pretty Fellow in the Middle, will make Amends for Beggary, and Madness.
Here's Mr. Freeman! Leave your Sniveling, and mind your Obedience, I command you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Souls know no Command, tho' Bodies do.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I deny that Position! I am all yours — All, and All, and ev'ry Part.
—Command, and try your Power.

p.hi: It shall be then, to see my Face no more.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: A very extraordinary Wife, I'm like to have, truly! —Very singular in her Manners, Faith!—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh, never mind what a Woman says, or does, before Marriage. She'll be gentler after.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: That's doubtful; for I can't perceive her to have the least Inclination for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Pish, pish; when you have been Married a Night or Two, you'll tell me another Story, Mr. Freeman — Her Mother was thus before her.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I wish it may prove so, Sir Philip:
sp.l: For who by Force the Courted Bliss receives▪
Ne'er tastes the Joy the Willing Fair-One gives.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
WAS ever Man so Cheated, Chous'd, and Cuckolded, as I am? By a Priest too, a Pox of his Sanctity! Well, this was an admirable Contrivance. Little did she think, who was her Ghostly Father. Ah! the Wickedness of this Age! Ah! Tim! Tim-Watchit! all thy Care is vain. Zounds! why did I grope for what I fear'd to find? I was but a Cuckold in Conceit before; now ev'ry Fool will hang his Hat upon my Horns! Oh! that I had her in Spain! I'd Spitch-cock her, like an Eel. — But just Revenge is counted Murder, in our Country; and a Man must be Hang'd for doing himself Justice.— This Priest must be a Conjurer! he must have some Charm to make me sleep sound; or, he cou'd never have come to Bed, and I not hear him. Nay, she says ev'ry Door in the House flies open as soon as he approaches.— These are fine Holy Guides, truly; No wonder there's so many Female Proselytes, when the Priests take so much Pains to Convert 'em.—Which way shall I be Reveng'd of this
Cuckold-making Dog? [Pauses] —No, that won't do.—Ay, it must be so.— Goes to the Scene, and calls. Pud, Why Pud, where are you, Pudsey?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Did you call, Snub?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Snub! Why how many Names must I have, ha? Snub! Pray who taught you that Name, Wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Taught me! Why, do you think I don't know how to put four Letters together?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Ay, the Priest has taught her the Art of Coupling; Pox take him for't. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: But what did you call me for?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: To tell you that some Affairs oblige me to go out of Town to Night; and that you must not take it ill, if I lock you into the House, that Nobody may come in or out, till I come back.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Ay, into my Chamber if you please; I begin to Relish my Confinement tolerably well— But may it not be dangerous to Travel so late?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: For her Ghostly Father, it may, if I catch him. [Aside.] No, no, not at all. Go, get you to your Chamber, Pud, I'll follow you; perhaps I may take a Nap before I go.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: I wish it might be your Last.— Lucy shall give Mr. Freeman Notice of this lucky Opportunity, [Aside.] Well, as you please, Snub: I'm all Obedience. Exit.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p:
If you were, Snub, I shou'd be too Happy. Ah! She is a delicious Bit! a tempting Morsel. Ah! these Priests! these pamper'd Priests! What wou'd become of good old English Property, had they once Footing here again? S'death, what had I to do with Beauty? What Business had I for a Wife, a handsome Wife? Of all Men living, I'm the most unqualify'd for a Husband! Husbands shou'd be kind, sociable,
courteous, gentle, loving, blind Animals; if they are so bewitch'd to pitch on Beauty.

lg.l: For he who Marries with a handsome VVife,
Engrosses all the Plagues of human Life.

div.head: SCENE changes to Mrs. Headless's House.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Headless on one side, and Fainwell on t'other.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: DUD yow call, forsooth,—Madam?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Jeffery, will you ever be this stupid Wretch, notwithstanding all the Pains I take with you? Is not Madam, as soon, and as easily pronounc'd as Forsooth?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay, every whit, d'ye zee, an I cou'd but hit on't; but my Memory is short, an yow hare a-body zo, that yow fright it out o' one's Head agen— Madam.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Hare you, Quotha! I'm sure you Craze me. You behave your self so awkardly before Strangers, they will believe, perhaps, that I don't understand better. When I'm alone, I don't care: Nay, sometimes your Blunders conduce to my Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I cou'd find a way more conducive to her Pleasure, if she'd give me leave. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: There's Mistress; An yow mun gi't her yowr zelf; gi't her, an yow wol.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My Master, Madam, gives his humble Service to you; and begs the Favour of an Answer.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I admire your Master will give himself and me this Trouble, when I have so often assur'd him 'tis to no purpose.

div.stage: Opens the Letter, and looks over it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Sure, I have seen your Face before, Brother.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ma hap, yow may, Friend, and ma-hap, yow mayn't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Are'n't you Gloucestershire?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Yes, I am.—I won't deny my Country.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is not your Name Crumplin?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay, marry, is it; be mess, I shou'd know yow too!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Honest Jeffery Crumplin! I'm glad to see thee. Kisses him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: P'shaw! I dan't like this zame slabbering Vashon.—But, pray, what may one call yow? I know yow'r Face.—Ah.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My Face! Why I can't be so alter'd in Six or Seven Years, sure! my Name is Sly!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Odd sa' me! Sam Sly! gi' me thy Hond, [Shakes him by the Hand.] Well, an how! an how have yow done, Sam, e'er sen we us'd to break one another's Head at Cudgels, ha? they told me yow was gon over Seas.—

sp.speaker: Sam▪
sp.p: I han't been in England above Six Weeks.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Say yow zo! Good lack! Well, an have yow bin in Gloucestershire?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, I came from thence but t'other Day; I liv'd with Mr. VVorthy.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: What, Master VVorthy of VVorthy-Hall?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Odd, yow had rare luck, hark-ye, to light on zo brave a Place. Well, an dud yow zee our Volk? how do Vather, and Mother, and Sisters? Ha?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: All well, and brisk, Jeffery.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Odd, Master VVorthy is a main honest Man.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: As lives by Bread, and as well belov'd.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Ha! these two Fellows are acquainted, I find. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: They wou'd have my Master set up for Parliament-Man.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I wish he were qualify'd for it. [Aside.] An he does, I'm zure he'll carry't: An Mr. VVorthy comes to Rule the Roast, we shall zee better Times, I'm perswaded. —Well! besure I'm huge glad to zee yow, Sam.—Where may a body zee yow, some Day to drink a Pot to all our Friends in Gloucestershire? ha? I have zome there, I believe; ha?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'll call on you some Evening, and shew you where I live.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr. Worthy writes me word, that he is going to Jamaica. It is only a Pretence, I suppose. I'll hear what his Servant says [Aside.] Is your Master going to Travel, young Man?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not for his Pleasure, Madam—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I did not speak of Pleasure; I ask'd you, if he is going Abroad?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It is in your Power to stop him, I believe, if he is, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Still foreign to my Question! Can't you answer directly, Friend?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That depends so entirely upon your Ladyship, that it is impossible to answer you directly.— I know he has an Uncle dead in Jamaica, that has left him Forty Thousand Pounds; but I also know▪ he is so much in Love with your Ladyship, that he does not care Forty Shillings for't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The Fellow's Mad! Not care for Forty Thousand Pounds? Why, the fourth Part on't wou'd purchase a Barony!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: If I had the Sixth Part of it, I'm sure thou shoud'st never purchase me. [Aside.] What! is that zame Uncle dead, that came over once with a huge sight o' Blackamoors at's Tail?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Jeffery! he's Dead.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Is he zo? He was mainly Rich, chu'd seem?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are mainly Impertinent, chu'd seem.— Pray, ask your Country-Man here, if he puts in his Verdict, when his Master's talking?—Pray tell, Mr. Worthy, that I shall be at Home all this Evening; and he may, if he pleases, give me an Opportunity of wishing him a good Voyage.—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: To the Island of Matrimony? or I shall make but a broken Voyage of it. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I shall inform him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How came you to know this Gentleman, Jeffery?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Who! Master Worthy! Why ev'ry Body knows him in Gloucestershire; Vather has work'd for him, and the old 'Squire, these Twenty Years chu'd seem. He's a fine Man, and has no more Pride in him, than I have. He keeps a topping House—He has humming March Beer! and deadly strong Cyder! There's rare Doings at Cursmas.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What Doings?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Why, he keeps open House for all Comers.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He ought to be very Rich; whose Oeconomy is so Profuse.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Rich, Quotha! Nouns, he knows no End of his Means; he has a mort o' Land! I ha' seen a Hundred; Nay, be mess, I known't an there warn't two Hundred, at Dinner in the great Hall, one Plough-Monday; All his own Tenants; an Master was so familiar and so merry wi' 'em, and made 'em zo Drunk! Lord, what Work was there! —

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It was a beastly Pleasure; and no Sign of his Frugality, whatever it may be, of his Good-Nature.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
Ah! he's the sweetest natur'd Man in the World. Nobody ever saw him out of Humour, that ever I cou'd hear on: His Vather, indeed, wou'd
bawl, and make a noise, chu'd seem; but as for thick same Gentleman, he's quite another Thing; he is so good to the Poor, and so loving to all his Neighbours; that there's not a Man Twenty Miles round him, but wou'd run thro' Fire and Water for him.— He is counted a main wise Man too; he makes no more of a Lawyer, or a Justice of the Peace, than, than, than, yow do of me, Madam.— Nay, it's thought by zome Volk, that he is so deep Learn'd, than an he wou'd, he cou'd puzzle, even the Parson o' the Parish.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That may be; and he no Conjurer, neither. He shall know what a Favourite he is of yours.—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That he knows already. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You seem to know him perfectly well.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I wish you knew him as well,—Madam!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is pity he is not a Man of Quality; These Qualifications, tho' I confess they are very bright ones, signify nothing without a Title, Jeffery!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I'm sure thy Vanity will never intitle Thee to the Heart of any Man of Sense. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go, get me some Tea.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Did I not hope to Command in my Turn; I shou'd not Obey so readily. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: There's a Lady below, that want's yow, she says,—Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Bring her up. — This must be the Lady Sir John, mention'd.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: 'Tis from Olivia, Madam.

div.stage: Gives her the Letter, she opens it, and reads.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are Welcome, Madam.—I'll wait on you to that Appartment my Cousin mentions. It is impossible Mr. Freeman shou'd know it to be any part of my House, when he is brought in by the Back-Door; Your own Servants must attend; I'll give Orders that none of mine are seen on that side of the House.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I am extreamly oblig'd to you, Madam. I have sent a Servant with a Letter to Mr. Freeman, and expect his return every Moment. —I'll wait on you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to walk this way. Exeunt.

div.head: The SCENE draws, and Louisa comes forward, meeting Flora.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: IS Frederick come back, Flora?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Yaw, ye Vrow, an he heb dat Lettre gi brought.

div.stage: Gives her a Letter. Exit Flora.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What Pleasure once these Letters gave me!
And with what Eagerness I broke the Seals!
Then kiss'd and dwelt upon each poison'd, pleasing Vow!
And thought the Perjury all Faithful Love.
—But now! —
I fear to read; so much his Stile is alter'd! —

body.p: I AM not more surpriz'd to hear you are in England, than that you so earnestly desire to see me before I am marry'd. But since you promise it shall be the last Trouble you'll give me of this kind, I design to oblige and wait on you immediately, to know your important Business. If it be to upbraid me with past Conduct, you must expect but a short Visit, from

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Perfidious Man! well may'st thou fear to stay,
To hear those Solemn Vows repeated
Which thou didst make so falsely.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Here bin Minheer Freeman, ye Vrow.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Shew him up. [Exit Flora.]
Oh! my Heart! —Lie still, thou Flutterer!
And aid me all the Cunning Courage of my Sex!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: That cold Salute, is nothing like my Freeman. You was not wont to kiss me thus!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I keep no Journal of my Pleasures; so can't recollect how I us'd to behave my-self.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: With what Indifference he regards me! Hold in, Resentment. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what brought you to England?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Do you ask, why I follow where you lead me? Where shou'd I be, but where my Husband is?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Hold, hold, — You'll spoil my Marriage — Husband! ha, ha, ha! Don't you rave, Child!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Have you forgot the Promises you made me?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No, nor what you gave me in Return, neither, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Did you not love me, Freeman?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Did I not give thee Proofs of it? How does my Boy do? Ha? I think you must lend him me for a Pattern. You have heard I am going to be Married, I find.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Yes — I've heard such News, but cannot think it true. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I can't help that. Nay, nay, nay, if you are at that sport, good-bye t'ye. — Going, she stops him.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: You shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Indeed but I shall, Madam. —Pish! prithee shew me none of your Tragedy-Airs. Let go my Coat. You know, I hate to see Women cry. — To what purpose are these Tears? —I thought I gave you a Caution of it in my Letter.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: O do not struggle to be gone; but hear me; My Tears will fall; but I'll strive to suppress 'em.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Do so; For if you have any thing to say to me, you must deliver it in a more entertaining manner, or I'm your humble Servant. Again! Humph! —I imagin'd how 'twou'd be. —'S'Death! what a Fool was I to come? I hate Upbraidings of this Nature.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I sent not for you to upbraid you.
I see too well I've lost your Heart.
May she be Happy who enjoys it now.
Yet sure your Pity's not extinguish'd too.
Not for my sake, but for your Child's, I hope it;
Who, if you relieve him not, must perish. —
My Father, some Three Weeks ago, expir'd,
And left me but a Shilling to support me.
Nor have we upon Earth a Friend, if you're not one.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Well! and cou'd not you have told me this, without Whimpering! —Pox o' the old Dog! A Shilling! — What a Duce shall I do with this Heifer and her Calf now! She comes very unlucky too
at this Time. If Olivia shou'd hear of her, my Business will be done there. [Aside] —Send out your Maid, Louisa.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Leave the Room; But when I call, do as I directed. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: [Sitting down.] What do you pay for these Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Nothing. The People are related to a Friend of mine in Holland; from whom I brought a Letter. I believe they let no Lodgings. I wou'd not willingly trespass long upon them.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, my Servant shall take Lodgings for you. — Dry up your Tears, and come and kiss me. [Pulls her on his Knee, and kisses her.] You foolish Girl you, to blubber and spoil your Face at this Rate, when you have nothing else to trust to! [He wipes her Eyes.] —So, there! kiss me again, you Chit, you. —I'll take Care of you. I have a Man in my Eye; a Lord too; that is very fond of your Country-Women.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: What means my Dearest. Rises.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: To get thee a good Settlement. A Lord's Mistress lives as great as his Wife, and is as much respected in our Country. — And thou shalt be Initiated, according to Custom.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Monstrous, filthy Custom!
Indeed, my Freeman, I'll be only Thine:
For after thee, I ne'er can love another.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Pish, pish; Yes, yes, a hundred, I warrant thee —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Unkind, and Cruel! —Can I love—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, well, as to Love, that's not essential to a Mistress: Provided the Gallant has your Person, you may dispose as you think fit of your Inclination.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sometimes to see my Freeman, 's all I wish.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Well, well, you shall see me; but we must manage that Point with Prudence: There must be a Decorum observ'd at home. For if it shou'd reach my
Wife's Ear, it wou'd prevent my seeing you at all— Ah, Louisa! I wish the Lady I'm to marry, lov'd me as well as thou dost.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I hope she does.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No, faith, she says she hates me; so that, for ought I know, thou'rt in a fair Way to be reveng'd of me.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I wish it not, nor wou'd I seek Revenge on thee, more than on my own Heart —Flora! [Goes to the Scene, and calls] — You must drink something with me —

div.stage: Enter Flora, with Two Glasses of Wine on a Salver.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Come, Here's to your Future Happiness!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I'll pledge that Generous Toast, and kiss thee for't —Why this is as it shou'd be now. [Kisses her.] If Women understood their own Interest, they'd find us less prepar'd to resist the Force of their Good Humour, than all the Artillery of Tears, and Ranting! —Egad! methinks thou art as handsome now, as when I first enjoy'd thee: Lips, as soft, and panting Breasts as hard as ever! —Oh, you are a tempting Baggage! [Embracing her.] —What if we shou'd try to get a Girl to our Boy, Louisa?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: What! sin a-new, e'er we've repented of the past?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Sin! you silly Jade! Come, come, we'll repent once for all, my Dear. Pulling her.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: It must be quickly then — Or Life will be too short to do it!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Forgive me, Freeman! Thou art poison'd.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Ha!— Dye thou, then, from whose Hand I took it!
Draws, and runs at Flora.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: [Shrieking] Ah! ick heb nit dat ga don, Minheer —

div.stage: Louisa rises, and runs between the Maid and him.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: O spare the Maid, who acted by my Order,
And turn your Point on me, the sole Agressor.
I had no other Way to keep thee mine.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Am I then caught! poison'd! —What! Dye the Death of Rats! —Confusion! Murder'd by my Whore!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: No, I'm thy Wife, thou vile Detractor!
Thou wou'dst have made me that detested Thing! —
Shame on thy Project to expose thy Wife!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Wife! Name that no more, I charge thee,
Lest I forget thy Sex, and spurn thee from me!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Not name it! Yes, I will, whilst Living, name it.
Call to Mind, who witness'd to your Vows;
By whom your swore when first our Faiths were plighted.
It was by you All-seeing Power Above,
At whose Tribunal we shall soon appear.
Death summons now our trembling Souls to Tryal;
Stript of Excuses, Custom, and Evasion;
This guilty Deed of mine will fall on Thee.
There, there, our Marriage Contract is recorded;
There is a Judge from whom you can't Appeal:
Your Jury can't be Brib'd to save you:
Your casting Witness is your broken Vows!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Methinks, her Words pierce, like a Dagger, thro' me,
And more than ever now I wish to Live. —
Repair thy Fault, and call Physicians hither.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Call the kind Physician of the Soul,
Thy Body can receive no help from Art.
The Poison is too strong, t'admit of Antidotes.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Then Heav'n have Mercy on my Soul. Kneels.
O my Louisa! canst thou forgive me! Rises.
O could Revenge, the blackest Fiend in Hell,
Shroud itself beneath that Angel's Form?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Call't not Revenge, but Love. —Be Witness, Heav'n,
I drank the healing Draught, with greater, stronger
Gust of Pleasure, than others take rich Cordials,
To lengthen fleeting Life, which I despise.
Since in fair Fame I cou'd not live thy Wife,
My only Wish was, We might dye together.
Oh! my Heart!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: The Poison works! I feel it too in mine!
Oh! might I live to make thee Satisfaction —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And wouldst thou do it? wouldst thou marry me?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: As willingly as I did ever promise thee.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: My Soul revives at thy returning Vertue,
Only to bear the Rack of deep Despair. —
Now, now, I do repent the desp'rate Deed,
And wish my Freeman's Life a longer Date.
I shou'd have trod the Paths of Death alone!
But 'twill not be! — A few short Minutes hence
We both shall be no more!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Oh! Shock of Nature! Bitterness of Thought!
Oh! whither am I going? —
Haste! Let the Holy Man be call'd!
And 'tis most fit a Lawyer too be sent for.
Something I must adjust before I go. —
And then, oh! World, farewell! —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p:
Haste, Flora, and obey.
Exit Flora.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: I feel a strange Disorder in my Brain!
My Heart beats fast too, and my Spirits flutter!
My boiling Blood runs swiftly thro' my Veins,
In haste to Man the Last Retreat of Life!
Oh! Louisa! wou'd I had Marry'd thee —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Do it now. 'Twill wipe off many Sins from thee,
When we appear in t'other World together —
The vertuous Act may plead my Pardon too.
If thou canst but forgive the Rashness of my Love.
Again, upon my Knees I ask it.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: As willingly, as I would be forgiven!
A sudden Faintness seizes me all o'er:
I will be thine, if Life will last so long.

lg.l: Blest Sound! —Come, lean on me.
I'll lead thee to my Bed,
Where we will rest, and wait the Holy Man.
Our Bridal Bed! from whence we both shall rise,
Disrob'd of Scandal, to substantial Joys!

div.head: SCENE changes to Watchit's House.
div.stage: Mrs. Watchit in a Night-Dress on a Couch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I Wonder what carries my Husband out of Town, so late? But no Matter, it gives me an Opportunity to see Freeman, who I know will be here as soon as Lucy has given the Signal — Ha! sure I heard the Door go.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I have unluckily forgot my Powder-horn; and how I shall find it in the Dark, I can't tell. — I don't care to disturb the Family for a Candle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: He is here already! — Oh, the dear impatient Man! — Bless me, Lucy, why did you let him come so soon? I don't think your Master is got out of the Street yet.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How's this? Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And if he should take it in his Head to come back, I should be terribly frighted.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Ounds! I'm Thunder-struck! this Dog of a Fryer is here already! and of Lucy's bringing! Oh! the Jade! Ad's-heart! I might have waited without Doors 'till Dooms day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Distraction! What have I said? —It is my Husband's Voice! What will become of me now!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Here needs no Conjuration. My Turtle seems willing enough to coo with him; and is only afraid I should return to spoil Sport. O the Strumpet! But let me hear what this Rogue answers. Which way will she get off now, I wonder? Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I have no Pretence to get off, but by going on. [Aside.] Well, Lucy tells me you are the most dextrous Fellow at this Business —

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Business! What are they come to Business, already?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I know not why; but methinks, I'm half afraid to venture on a Stranger.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: A Stranger! What, then this is a new Rogue? —Ounds! I shall be Cuckolded by Church and State!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: How now! What do you mean? You won't offer to come to Bed to me, sure?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You'll take it very ill if he don't. — Ounds, I han't Patience to hear it out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: O Gemini! What do you do? —How dare you be so rude?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: There's a Question to ask a Man that she has brought into her Bed-Chamber!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: If my Husband should come!

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: As he really is. —

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: If he should catch you! —

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: As he most surely will — Thou Sorceress!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Nay, nay; Indeed, and indeed, but I won't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Indeed, and indeed, but you will. —This is a thorough-pac'd Cuckold-making Dog! —How softly the Villain whispers! — I can't hear one Word he says.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wat.
sp.p: What gave you the Assurance to imagine I'd Cuckold my Husband, who is the best of Husbands?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That's a Lye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Let me go, will you? I protest I'll cry out.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That's another Lye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Nay; Lord! —Pish; don't, —Fy! —What do you do?

div.stage: Speaks as if she was struggling with somebody.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'S'Death! I shall stand and hear my-self Cuckolded! — A Light! a Light, there! Thieves, Thieves! A Light a Light! —

div.stage: She rises hastily. He pulls out a Pistol.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wat.
sp.p: Ah, Heavens! what Noise is that? Why Lucy, Lucy! Thieves, Thieves! A Light! a Light! [She gropes about, and lays hold on his Pistol.] Thieves! —Ah, a Pistol! Murder! Murder! Oh save my Life, and I'll lead you to all the Money, Plate, and Jewels in the House. Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Mumps! Oh, save me, save me!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Off, thou foul Adultress! Don't think to smuggle me, 'till your lewd Paramour escapes.

div.stage: Snatches the Candle, and looks about.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Bless me, Madam! Master looks as if he would eat a-Body! What was all this Outcry for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p:
I'll tell you anon.
Aside to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Where have you hid this Rogue of your providing, Hussey? Ha?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Of my providing? What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wat.
sp.p: Nay, nay, don't stand prating; but call up the Servants to assist your Master. —Don't, dear Mumps, don't be too venturesome. The Thieves have Pistols, and may kill thee.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: May they so! A Pox o' your Sneer. —Now does she look as if she knew not one Word of the Matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I hope to prevent your knowing one Word of the Matter, that's my Comfort. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why what should she know, Sir?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Go look, Mrs. Pander.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I'm sure, I know nothing, but that I was wak'd with the Cry of Thieves, Thieves! If it was a false Alarm, so much the better: It did me Service, however, for it wak'd me out of a Dream, that frighted me as bad as the Noise did.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: A Dream! Why, what was you dreaming on, pray?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Why, methought Lucy had brought me a Corn-cutter, a great, fat, clumsey, black Fellow; but the most dextrous Fellow in the World, she told me, at that Business.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: [Aside.] Ha! I remember dextrous was one of the Words she spoke. Perhaps it might be nothing but a Dream.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And the impudent ugly Villain, methought, would have come to Bed to me. I was strugling with him in my Sleep, and vowed I'd cry out, just as the Noise wak'd me.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, Pud! And was all this splutter about a Corn-cutter? — Why then, to tell thee the Truth, thou didst cry out, and I thinking Thieves were got into my House, cry'd out too; for I never dream't of thy talking in thy Sleep, Child. —I don't remember ever to have heard thee before.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So have I, a hundred times; but you snore so loud, that no-body's Noise can be heard but your own. —This Corn-cutter has put the Corn-maker out of his Head. I smell the Plot already. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Aside.] It takes, as I could wish — But where was Freeman, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Gone out, Madam. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Aside.] 'Twas lucky that he was.— Ah, Mumps! I know what you thought.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, he thought you had got a Gallant through the Key-hole. Had I a Husband of Master's Temper, I'd fit him, I warrant him. He should not be jealous of me for nothing.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: That I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: As you are of my Lady. She has a comfortable Life, has she not? To have you vex and teize, and break her Rest for nothing.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Take care I don't break your Head for something.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I care not if you do. I will speak. You could not use my Lady worse, if she had Cuckolded you. —You are like some litigious Farmers, who Pound their Neighbours Cattle for a Trespass, tho' they have more Ground, than they can stock themselves.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Hussey! You have Stock for the whole Parish! —Get out of my Sight, or I'll break your Neck down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Excellent Wench! [Aside.] Fy, Lucy, how you talk to your Master? I assure you, I shall discharge you my Service, if you don't behave your self better.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I shall get another, I hope, if you do? Don't think I'll be suspected of procuring Gallants for you! Did he not ask, where the Rogue was of my Procuring? — I'll bring my Action against you, for Scandal. I have nothing but my Reputation to live by. Take That from me, and you take all. If he's your Husband, Madam, he's not mine. Bursts into Tears.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, thank Heaven, I have enough of one of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Leave the Room, I say.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: It's for, for, your Sake — or, or —I'd tear his Eyes out! [Sobs.] Take away my Reputation! Exit.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Oh! the wondrous Reputation of a Chambermaid! —This Slut has strangely provok'd me. I wish I were rid of her. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: [Aside.] I wish I knew what brought him back; and if he intends to go again.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: [Aside.] Ah! that the Husband of that Charming Woman should be Cornuted by a Priest! —

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: [Aside.] What would I give to be rid of his Company? Yet I dare not ask him, how he designs to dispose of himself, for my Soul.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: What art thou thinking of, Pudsey?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Of your Unkindness, Mumps! To pretend Business out of Town, and leave me starving in Bed by myself. I'm sure if you lov'd me, you would not let Business take you from my Arms. Indeed, indeed, you would not, Mumpsy.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Ah! those pretty Pouters! I must kiss them, thou coaxing Pug, thou! [Kisses her.] Dost thou really love thine own Mumpy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Naughty Mumps! is that a Question now! Han't I given you all the Signs of it? Don't I lie close to your Back? and warm your Feet every Night in my Lap? And creep gently out o' Bed in the Morning, without waking you? Don't I? Can you deny this, Mumps?

sp.speaker: VVat
sp.p: No, nor I won't deny it, Pudsey. And I hope you'll allow me some Merit in my Turn, Pudsey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Nay, Mumps, I scorn to derogate from your Merit. I must confess, you never do any thing to break my Rest, but when you are so naughty to leave me. —For then I do so tumble, and toss — and dream —and am so terribly frighted —as I was but now, you know. —Well, I protest, you shan't go out again to Night! — If you do, I won't love you again these Three Days; so I won't.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Thou handsome Creature! Oh! 'twas that bewitching Leer, that snapt my Heart —What has she in her Head now? —I never knew her in this wheedling Humour, but she had some Design [Aside.] —Well, Pudsey, What is that begging Face put on for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: That's a Secret, past your finding out. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What can I do to please my Pudsey?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: E'en very little truly. [Aside] —I could tell you, Mumpy; but may be, you won't do it.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: But may be I will do it. In a fond Tone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Won't you go out no more to Night, then? But say your Prayers, and go to Bed, and snore like any little Pig in your Punny's Bosey?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: [Aside.] Humph! Now is she afraid of her Ghostly Father. She certainly smokes my Design. — On my Conscience, she's in Love with him. —I warrant, he's a strapping young Dog. —Ounds! if I can but light of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: What is he pondering on? Pray Heaven he does not take me at my Word, and stay at Home in Complaisance. [Aside.] —What won't you answer me, Mumps?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Why, Pudsey, thy Kindness so confounds me, that I know not what to answer thee. —I am loth to displease thee, and yet I must leave thee instantly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: [Aside.] Little does he think, that 'tis the only thing he can do to please me. I hope Freeman is come home by this Time.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: I only came back for my Powder-horn; that's all, Pud; but I'll make all possible haste back: I will indeed, Pudsey, to make thee easy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Or otherwise. [Aside.] Well! if it must be so! [Sighing.] I must be content, and make my self as happy as I can without you, Mumps.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, I won't be long from thee. Go, prithee, get me a Dram, I'll but take my Powder-horn, and follow thee —
Exit Mrs. Watchit.

sp.speaker: VVatchit Solus.
sp.p: I know not what to think. Sometimes I think she loves me — and sometimes I think she does not. And if Father Domini comes within the Reach of my Blunderbuss, have at him! If not, she shall produce him: I'll confront her with her own Confession. If once I get him in my Power, I'll turn his own Inquisition upon him. His Church ne'er tortur'd Heretick, as I will him.

lg.l: I'll teach him to keep Handmaids of his own,
And let his honest Neighbour; VVives alone.

div.head: SCENE Mrs. Headless's House.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I AM strangely divided between Inclination and Grandeur. I confess, I like Mr. Worthy's Person better than my Lord's; but marry him, and I shall be call'd plain Mrs. Worthy: Then, where's the Distinction between me and my Butcher's Wife: And who in their Senses wou'd part with Twenty thousand Pounds, to be nothing but what one was before? My Lord can make me a Woman of Quality, and intitle me to treat all below me with Contempt. That carries a valuable Consideration. —Methinks, there is an Air in the very Footman of a Woman of Quality. He approaches with such profound Submission! And in a Tone so Soft, —Did your Ladyship call, Madam? Whereas, now, my blundering Rascals come trotting up to my Nose, with a Dud you want me, Forsooth? — Ha! Lord Pharoah-Bank.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I hope you'll pardon this abrupt Intrusion, Madam. It is intirely chargeable on the Impatience of my Love. Command my Absence, I beseech you, if I break in upon your more diverting Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I had no Amusements, my Lord, but what ought to give way to better Company.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: You do me a particular Honour in that Distinction.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If I had not some Skill in the Choice of my Acquaintance, I should be stifled with Impertinence. The first Lesson I teach my Servants, is, To distinguish between Persons of Rank, and the Dross of Human-kind. I am pleas'd to find my Instructions are not lost upon 'em, by admitting one of your Lordship's Figure upon such easy Terms.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Such an Approbation from a Lady of your good Taste, cannot fail of inspiring me with a better Opinion of my-self, and a Confidence of my not being unwelcome to my Dear Widow. [Kisses her.] She kisses softer than a Southern Wind!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pugh! I hate to be Complimented with Fragments of another's Wit, my Lord. It argues a Decay of Charms in the Person you address.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I own it is a Fault, Madam. Your Ladyship has Beauty enough to inspire the dullest Genius with something New.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] You mean, she has Money enough to inspire you with Impudence.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Apollo and the Muses dwell upon these Lips. Another Kiss, and I shall be—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A Poet?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Whatever you wou'd have me. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Say you so, my Lord? I have an odd Whim come into my Head.—Will you give me a Proof of my Power, my Lord? I want an Elegy.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: On a departed Monkey, or a Favourite Kitten, I presume.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: No, upon a Living Subject.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] A pretty new Invention, to bury People before they are dead.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: A Living Subject! An Elegy upon a Living Subject?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: You are not inspir'd yet, I find, my Lord. I mean, a Characteristick of human Life; Dead, and yet Existing.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] Mystery!

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Popery! Downright Popery! May the Genius of England defend us.—Let me see! What dead Folks have we among the Living? —There's a Disbanded Officer.—An old Beau.—A broken Tradesman. —A Degraded Parson.—A Quondam South-Sea Director. —An Eunuch. —An, an, an Old Maid.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: You have hit it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Then Crown my Success with another Draught of Nectar. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] How warmly the Rogue Kisses! He makes Love with as much Assurance, as if he had Two Bottles of Burgundy in his Belly, and a real Title to support his Impudence.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I protest, one shou'd take your Lordship for a Soldier; for you attack a Woman, as they do a Fortify'd Town.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Love, and War agree in every Point, my dear Widow; The Blockade of a Town resembles an obstinate Woman, and a Phlegmatick Lover, who resolves to weary her into Compliance. A Kiss now and then from a diffident Lover, is like stealing a March, and surprizing the Enemy, by a circumspect General. But eager and repeated Kisses, are, like Storming, more glorious to the Assailant.

stage.hi: Embracing and Kissing her in a Rapture.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] These Rogues happen into good Company sometimes, one may know by their Gleanings of Wit.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Oh gad, my Lord, what do you mean, by Ruffling one at this Rate?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Judge my Meaning, by the Quickness of my Pulse, the Throbbing of my Heart, and Trembling of my Limbs! The unquestionable Proofs of Love, and Eager Wishes for Possession. —Come, come! Thou art no Stranger to a Lover's Meaning!—My Life, my Soul! Let us improve this Dawn of Pleasure.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: As how, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] Sure she wou'd not have him tell her in plain Terms.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: P'shaw! for a Woman of thy Experience, to ask that Question!—Come, come, the Sight of the Bed-Chamber, will refresh thy Memory.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: —Pish! —Nay, fy—Be Civil, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: [Aside.] Humph! — If it be come to Pish, and Fy already, another Volly of Kisses, and she surrenders at Discretion.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Nay, Struggling is your Sex's Privilege. You wisely know Resistance but inflames Desire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I protest, I'll cry out, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: With all my Heart. Your Servants know their Duty better than to come, if you do. — Honest Jeffery has taken Care of that. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: How secure the Rogue thinks himself! Aside.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I will positively enjoy thee this Night — Honourably, if you please.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Or not at all, my Lord, if you were the First Man of Quality in England!

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Send for the Parson this Minute then.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Oh Gad! You stop one's Breath.—You are the most impatient Man! —

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Impatient, quotha! Who can behold these dear Eyes without Impatience for the Blessing?—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, let us sign Articles:— And then—

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: I'll give thee a Chart-Blanche. Make thy own Terms; so that I may this Night take Possession of these Arms.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Well, since your Lordship will have it so—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, yow mou'not go in, an yow were Ten Master Worthess— [In his own Voice.] [Fainwell within, in Jeffery's Voice.] I tell you, I had your Lady's Commands to wait on her, and must, and will go in: So, sweet Mr. Jeffery Crumplin, by your Leave.

div.stage: Fainwell rushes in, in his own Dress.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Oh Gad! that's Mr. VVorthy's Voice! What can he think, when he see's one ruffled in this Manner! —I'm surpriz'd!—Did not I hear my Clod-hopper's Voice, in a resisting Tone, Mr. VVorthy?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I was so far out of my Country-man's good Graces, that he wou'd neither bring in my Name, nor permit me to enter.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: [Aside.] That was in Favour of me. Jeffery is a Man of Honour, I find.—But who's this Mr. VVorthy? Disappointment catch him, for coming so Mal-a-propos.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: That Fellow is the most impenetrable Sot!— Why did not you break his Head, Mr. Worthy?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That's a Liberty, Madam, no Man ought to take in your House, 'till you have made him Master of it.—Were I that happy Person—

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: [Stepping in between them.] You'd kick everybody out of it, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That gives me just Provocation, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: If they shou'd quarrel now!—Mr. VVorthy, pray let me speak a Word with you.—Do you know who this Gentleman is?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Then if you know me, you know your Distance. Steps between again.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So well, Sir, [Goes between 'em.] that were you not protected by this Lady's Presence, there shou'd be just the Distance from hence to the Street between us.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: How, Sir? Stepping up to him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Through the Window, Sir. Pushes him away.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: You dare not talk thus elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: You dare not give me an Opportunity.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Dear Mr. VVorthy, for your own sake, consider what you do.—He is a Man of Quality; and, for ought I know, a Privy-Counsellor.—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: To nothing above a Gang of Pick-pockets, I'll answer for him. Hark-ye, Tally; how long have you worn this Surtout of Honour, I beseech you? In what Reign were you created a Baron, pray?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: Humph! He knows me, I find.—My Business is done here.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: My Stars! Is not he a Man of Quality?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, I'll give you his Titles in a very few Words.—He is Baron of Fair-Chance, and Viscount of all the Pharoah-Tables in and about London. He has a Pack of Cards for his Coat of Arms, quarter'd with Knaves; and False Dice, in a Field of Impudence.—His Crest is a Fool; his Supporters, are Parolie, and Trait la va.

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: [Aside.] The Rogue has Blazon'd me!— But I must carry it off as well as I can.—I hope you'll prove this, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Oh! instantly, Sir.—Sam!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Call a Constable.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Not for the World. I beg I may have no more Bustle in my House.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
You understand me.
VVhispers to Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Perfectly well.—Will your Lordship please to walk this Way— What think you, my Lord, of a Pot of Porter, to drink to our better Acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p:
A Pox of Ill-luck!—I may find a Time, Sir—
Exit with Sam.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Not to cheat me of my Money, Sir.—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I hope you are not mistaken in the Man, Mr. VVorthy.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I'm glad You were not, Madam.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Which is intirely owing to your timely Discovery, or I had been undone.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: For which, give me leave to say, you might have thank'd your own Vanity. Nothing but a Lord wou'd go down!—I admire, a Woman of your Discretion, and a Widow too! shou'd prefer Empty Title to Real Pleasure, and mere Shadow to conjugal Affection. Embracing her.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: A Fiddle of Affection, Mr. VVorthy; I tell you, I have been Lac'd very tight once in my Life; but having made my Fortune, and got my Liberty, if ever I try again the Matrimonial Bodice, the Lace shall be tagg'd with a Title, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ah! that will make a Noise in the World; but your Pleasure, like a Squib, will vanish in the Bounce, ha, ha, ha! —To give Twenty thousand Pounds for the bare Name of my Lord's Lady, whilst Ten to One, but your Chamber-maid supplies your Ladyship's Place in his Arms, and rattles about Streets in her Berlin, supported out of your Ladyship's Fortune.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: You seem well acquainted with the Map of this World.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Perfectly, Madam; and have made this Observation, That Women who love to indulge their Vanity, and yet hope for their Dividend of Pleasures, are acting as inconsistent a Part, as they who give a Loose to their Fancy, and at the same Time think to preserve their Reputation.—I tell you, Madam, A Man of Quality will no more throw all his Love upon a Wife, than a Farmer will sow all his Land with the same Grain. The only Way to engross your Joys, is to marry one of us Country-Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: To be rival'd by March-Beer, Tobacco, and Fox-hounds.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Even those are preferable to Cards, Dice, and a Wench, as you wou'd have experienc'd, had not I come in.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: So! now will he value himself upon my Deliverance. [Aside.] —Well, well, Mr. VVorthy, since this Fellow proves a mere Plebeian, he is a worthless Rascal; but if he had really been a Lord, what is now Impudence, wou'd only have been the Violence of his Love.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Humph! a very pretty Distinction! —No, Madam, I deny that Position—Love is soft and gentle, as the Morning-Sun in Autumn, mellowing Inclination by Degrees; but its Twin-Brother, like a Foot-Pad, knocks you down, and rifles you at once.— He was impatient for your Money only, Widow.— I, for this dear Person.—Now, why can't you like me as well as a Lord?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Like you! For what?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: For what! Why for an unalterable, faithful, constant Doating—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir. Your Epithets are running away with your Meaning. — But to prevent your explaining it, I must tell you, That the very Name of Matrimony with a Commoner, will flatten our Conversation, and make us look very simple.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay! but there is something so expressive in that Simplicity, that it gives a deeper Impression than all the Gildings of Rhetorick. Ah! my dear, Widow, wou'd you but return my Love, how many Cupids shou'd I behold dancing in these Eyes! Nay, and you shou'd see strange Things before Morning.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sha! you talk foolishly.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: That's inherent to a Lover.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And so you'd have me a Fool too, to keep you in Countenance. A very wise Foundation for the Fabrick of Matrimony.—No, no, I tell you once for all, Though I do like your Person, you and I must never be conjur'd into the Circle of a Wedding-Ring.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: And no other Circle will do my Business.— I'll try if she has really a Liking for my Person.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well! what have I put you in the Dumps, now? Are you considering what Death will revenge you of an ungrateful Mistress. Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, faith, Madam; I'll live to be reveng'd, and balk your Vanity—
sp.l: Then farewell Love;
Farewell Love, and all soft Pleasure,
Honour calls, and we must part.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are the merriest Lover at parting!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I am of Ben's Mind, Madam; resolve to be merry, though the Ship were sinking. And since I must never hope to call you mine, I here dismiss all the Retinue of a formal Lover. Such as Vows, Ogles, Sighs, Dreams, Visions, Sonnets, Gingles, Epigrams, Couplets, with a long &c. —Thus, with infinite Struggles, I hope to entertain as mean an Opinion of Matrimony, as your Ladyship, in a very little Time.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh! that he had a Title to support this Humour; he shou'd find, I have no mean Opinion of Matrimony. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: And, for the future, shall look upon the Parson's Patchwork, like a Pilgrimage to Mecca, or Jerusalem, fit only for the Superstitious, and People who have periodical Inclinations, to fill up the Vacancies of human Life with a huge Caravan of Children; a long Journey; dirty Road; through the Turnpikes of Jealousy, Anxiety, Suspicion, Animosity, pinching Cares, and a Thousand other Inconveniencies.—By the way, you have travell'd the Stage, and, I suppose, know what I say to be true.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha! — All is not right within this Breast. I begin to perceive his Indifference gives me Pain.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I fancy the only Object to give one a Surfeit of Matrimony, wou'd be to see a Pair of distemper'd Creatures in the Corner of a Room, in close Conspiracy to deceive one another; very sincerely promising mutual Love for Fifty Years ensuing; when, upon Tryal, a Month's Fruition makes either a Caterwauling Correspondence, or a more peaceable and elegant Way, of Separate Beds.—She seems nettled, I'll proceed. [Aside.] —With this Thought I comfort my-self: And here, Madam, bid Matrimony and You Eternally Farewell—Who wou'd be led for Life.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Eternally! —I wish I had never seen this Fellow.—Lord, how my Heart sinks. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.l: Come all ye Winds, come all away,
And briskly in our Canvass play;
Waft me gently o'er the Main;
Farewell, Widow! Farewell, Pain!
Lara, dera, lara, dera, lal, lal, la!

div.stage: In the Tune of Over the Hills and far away.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are exceeding Gay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
Tous jour Gay, as the French say. I always meet the Frowns of Fortune thus—The Jade may jilt, but never inslave me.—But, to be serious, To morrow, Madam, I embark for the Indies. It will be
a secret Pleasure to me, if you'll permit this Paper Room in your Cabinet. It is my Last Will and Testament. If I miscarry in the Voyage, that will intitle you to Forty thousand Pounds, my Uncle's Death inrich'd me with in Jamaica; whither I am bound. This is a Proof of my Esteem, though you have forbid my Love.

div.stage: Gives her a Paper, and takes up a Book from the Table, and seems to look in't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This is an Act so singular, so full of Generosity, that it almost lays me under a Necessity of making you some Return.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Very singular, faith, if she knew all. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Forty thousand Pounds! —Why one Quarter of that Money, would buy a Barony.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Quarter me, if I wou'd lay it out that way, if I had it. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Or, suppose you shou'd sell Part of your Estate in, in, in — Gloucester-shire?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay! or any other Shire. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A Patent wou'd be no difficult Thing to obtain.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No! but the Money to pay for it, wou'd. Aside. Ha! —What's here, The Pleasures of a Single Life? Luckily Encounter'd! —

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: P'shaw! a Fiddle of Single Life!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, since you have impos'd the Study, Madam, you must give me Leave to con my Lesson.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pugh! now I'm serious, you are turning every Thing to Ridicule.—About this same Patent, I say; —Suppose you sell part of your Estate.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, my Estate is like a Wife, Intail'd; and my Father made me swear, never to levy a Fine upon any Consideration, but making a Lady a Joynture. So that it is like to be mine for Life.—But, I know, this sudden Pretence of yours, is only to try the Strength of my new Resolution.—You are not in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, pursue your Voyage to Jamaica; sell your Effects; return and purchase a Barony; which you may easily do, in Eight or Ten Months, and you shall see if I am in Earnest, or not.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Eight, or Ten Months! Ha, ha, ha! Men love not now, Child, the Patriarchal Way. No, no, I wou'd not trust to a Woman's Promise Eight or Ten Hours.—Marry me before I go, and then—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O! then you won't go at all.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Just the same as if you do not marry me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But what a ridiculous Figure I shall make, after so many Declarations against Plebeianism, when I shall be wish'd Joy by that vulgar Epithet—Mrs. Worthy?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: If that be an Objection, I'll give you my Honour, you shall never be call'd Mrs. Worthy — [Takes hold of her Hand, then snatches it away.] — O the Devil! that Touch has thaw'd all my Resolution, and Love and Folly begin to pour in like a Deluge: But when I think of those terrible Words, You and I must never be conjur'd into the Circle of a Wedding-Ring—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This is nothing to the Barony. Look-ye, Mr. Worthy, your Generosity has made this Moment yours; but if you don't take me at my Word, Consideration may spoil my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, I'm to be taken in the Moment too. Therefore, if you'll slip on your Hood and Scarf, step into a Hackney-Coach with me, and drive to the Fleet, where we may be tack'd together by a Spiritual Journey-man, without a License, or the Knowledge of either your Servants or mine; I promise you, as soon as the Ceremony is over, I'll on Board; make what haste the Wind and Waves will permit; Dispatch my Affairs with the utmost Expedition; and, with the first Ship, return to these dear Arms. 'Till when, 'till when, thy Widow's Name be worn. The World shall be insensible of my Happiness, 'till it rings with thy Honour.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And you'll perform this?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Most religiously— Embraces her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Nay, no more Fairy-Fancies: Give real substantial Pleasure. We Country-Gentlemen are so used to Surloyns of Beef, that we shall starve on the Whipt-Cream of Airy Promises —Take me, take me, whilst you may [Sings, then runs and catches her in his Arms.] This Moment, whilst my Hopes are high; whilst Imagination represents a Groop of Pleasures, thou'lt find thy Account in't, I warrant thee, Widow!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh! I can refuse the dear Man no longer.— Well, wait in a Coach at the Corner of the Street, and I'll be with you in the Compass of a Wish.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! she's caught, by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Joy to you, Sir! I over-heard the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Not a Word in the Family.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not for the World, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Wait you at my Lodging, with all Things in Readiness for Consummation.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Never fear my Part of the Business, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: What have you done with his Lordship?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Reduc'd him to a Commoner again, Sir; But, the Fellow is a reasonable Creature; provided you'll forgive him, he'll obey your Commands.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Very well! Away, and call me a Coach.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Yes. — Exit.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Egad, I've earn'd her Fortune by mere Dint of Policy.—Thus,
sp.l: When Truth, and Love, to win the Women fail,
A well-laid Plot, and Artifice, prevail. Exit.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Street, before Watchit's Door. He in Armour, with a Blunderbuss on his Shoulder, which he often makes ready to fire.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I Shall pepper this Dog, if he comes in my way.—Hark! Sure I heard somebody tread.— No, 'twas nothing but the Wind, I believe—'Tis very cold—I shall catch my Death; but it is better to die once for all, than to live upon the Rack. What had I to do with a Help-Mete, when I was no Mete-Help for her? S'Death, to be bubbled in my old Age; to father Children that I never got, and leave my Estate to a Mungrel Race, half Fish, half Flesh, a Piece of Priest-Craft! I have had, as it were, by Instinct, a sort of an Aversion to that kind of People from my Cradle. Ah! honest John Dryden, I shall never forget a Passage of thine.— Priests of all Religions— Who comes there? Stand, or you're a Dead Man.

div.stage: Enter Demur, who draws, strikes up Watchit's Piece, and disarms him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How! Villain—I'll see you fairly truss'd up, if I live.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Ounds, who are you, Sir? and what makes you sauntering here, at this Time of Night? You are a Rogue, Sirrah, and I'll secure you.—Watch, Watch, Watch.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That Pretence shan't save your Bacon, you old Villain you. Watch, Watch.

div.stage: Enter Sir John with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What's the matter here? Ha! Doctor Demur? You are not hurt, I hope!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Doctor Demur! Who the Devil's he? a Patch of the Law? or a Carcass mender? I expected a Botcher of another kind.— Aside.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No, not hurt, Sir John; but I was like to have had a Brace of Balls in my Guts.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who call'd Watch?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I did, Sir; Here's a Rogue attack'd me on the King's Highway, with a Design to Rob, and Murder me, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I did, Sir; This strapping young Dog disarm'd me, with Intention to enter my House Vi & Armis; plunder, and abuse me—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Your House! Where do you live, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir?—A Constable may Cuckold an Alderman. I don't desire any of you Night-walking Sparks shou'd know my House.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: A plain Case, a plain Case! he's asham'd of his Habitation; away with him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Mr. Constable, he's a Rogue! This is a worthy Gentleman, a Doctor of the Laws.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, Sir; I know Doctor Demur to be as honest a Man, as any in the whole Temple, and ruins as few, I believe. We'll Secure him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Do; I'll have him Examin'd before a Justice of the Peace in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
The Devil! This is a Trick to get me out of the way; and whilst I'm detain'd by these Scoundrels, that Dog of a Fryar will lie at Rack and
