Manger with my Wife. Pray hear me, Mr. Constable.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir, you shall be heard, before you go to Newgate.— You're a fine old Duke, to come to the Gallows at these Years. Come, bring him along.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sir, I say I'll go before a Justice to Night, and will have my Wife with me too. Zounds, I cou'd tear my Flesh.—Oh! Tim! Tim! that ever thou shou'dst Marry?

div.stage: Exit. Forc'd out by the Constable, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This shou'd be Fainwell's Uncle, by his talking of his Wife; and certainly mistook you for one of her Gallants.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Odso! I have heard Fainwell speak of him. If it shou'd be him, we shall have good Diversion. Where are you going, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am sent for by my Brother Ned; who, I am told, lies dangerously Ill at the Widow Headless's.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis thither I'm going; I am glad I met you: I hope it is for your Advantage.—I'll follow you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Haste shou'd excuse Ceremony, Doctor.

div.stage: Enter Constable and Watch, with Mr. Watchit and his Wife, and Lucy; meeting Sir Philip Money-love.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, come, bring them along to the Round-House.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Whither, cruel Man, must I be haul'd out of my Bed at this unseasonable Hour?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Only to the Watch-house, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: To the Watch-house! to the Devil, Sir! I'm a Gentleman, and won't be abus'd. Carry me before a Justice instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Phi.
sp.p: What's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Philip! Here, here's a Justice of Peace for you. This old Man, Sir! assaulted Doctor Demur.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You lye, Sir! he assaulted me, Mr. Justice—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; I can't hear you in the Street. My Cousin Headless lives at next Door, carry your Prisoners thither, Constable; you know the House, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, yes, very well, Sir. Come, come, bring 'em along. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Inside of Mrs. Headless's House.
div.stage: The Back-Scene Draws, and discovers Ned Freeman, and Louisa, just Married; (the Parson making his Exit) and Sir John and Demur; Louisa throws her Arms about Freeman's Neck.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: NOW I'm Happy! Now thou'rt mine again!
Look up, my Love! my Freeman!
My Joy! my Soul! my Husband!
Take, take me in thy Arms; and say,
Thou dost forgive me; or I'm still most wretched.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Ha! Why this Joy? From whence these Raptures,
When Life is on the Wing; and Death pursues it
With an Eagle's Swiftness?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Far be that Thought! far as my Wishes, send it!
I hope to hold thee many happy Years:
Thou art not Poison'd!
Forgive the Artifice that made thee mine.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha! not Poison'd!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You're in no Danger, I assure you, Brother; it was only your Surprize disorder'd you.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Give me leave to tell you, Brother, the Disorder I find my self in, cannot proceed from Surprize alone.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Something there was; but far from being fatal; The Doctor assur'd me, it wou'd have no other Effect than making you a little Sick for the present.—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And I assure you, Sir, that I am not to be Trick'd, Sir. [Draws] Cancel the Deed this moment, or—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Draws.] That, and my Life shall go together.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Ah! [Shreiks.] Murder! Murder!

div.stage: Enter Sir Philip, Watchit, Mrs. Watchit, Lucy, Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ha! Murder! I Charge you in the King's Name to keep the Peace, Mr. Constable. — What do I see! Mr. Freeman and the mad Knight!— What, wou'd you murder your Brother, Sir. Secure him, Constable. —I have been looking for you, Mr. Freeman, all the Town over.— D'ye hear, Step to my House, and bid my Daughter come to me this Minute. [To one of the Watchmen, who Exits.] Hark-ye, Mr. Freeman; was not there something to be done at my House to Night?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I thought so, Sir; but was unluckily prevented.—

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: This is the Rogue, that took me up, Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Did not you bid me Stand, Sir? and did not I disarm you of that Blunderbuss in the Constable's Hand, you old Thief, you?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Thief! I scorn your Words, Sir; I was upon my Guard.—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Guard of what, Sir?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Why, a Breach that's made in my Citadel here. Pointing to his VVife.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! By whom, pray?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Ask her that; she can tell you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, my Lady can tell you, what melancholy Days, and wretched Nights —

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: I'll wretched Night you, Hussey!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; do you consider where you are?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Yes, and what I am too.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: And what may that be, I pray?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: A Cuckold, Sir —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: If you are sure of that — Why— the Law is open, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Ay! so open! that it has swallow'd both Justice and Conscience; and yet is as Hollow as ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; But how came you arm'd? and to insult this honest Gentleman?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Have a care what you say, Sir; he'll bring his Action against you for Scandal — But I took him for just such another honest Gentleman; a Botcher of Consciences. One that has a better Knack at making Sin, than forgiving it.— My Wife knows what I say to be true; and my Intention was to have sent a Brace of Balls Hue-and-Cry thro' his Body, in Pursuit of his Continency.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Murder a Man for lying with your Wife! — Why, you shou'd take the Law of him.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: That the Lawyers might murder my Estate; No, I thank you; I'm for the shortest way; I'd rather hang at Tyburn, than in one of your Courts.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: Have you Witness of what you say, my Dear?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Yes, your self, my dear Devil —

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: I deny it; Produce your Evidence!

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Oh Impudence! Sir, Pray give her her Oath, and send her to the Devil at once—Did not you tell your Ghostly Father, Mistress, That a Fryar enjoy'd you every Night? deny that, if you can! Nay, and even when I was in Bed with you too! And that ev'ry Door in the House open'd as soon as he approach'd it! for which you believ'd him a Conjurer? A Pox on the Wizard, and the Circle too, I say— Now, Gentlewoman, can you safely take your Oath this was not your Confession?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: I can safely take my Oath, I go in danger of my Life with you.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis I go in Danger of my Life, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: That shall be try'd; for know, Sir, I can bear these base Insults no longer—I must not go abroad—Not so much as to Church; nor see any Company at Home; Not a Relation in Breeches; and whenever you take a Whim in your Head to go Abroad, I must not lie in my Bed, tho' you have the Key of the Door in your Pocket. Nay, in short, I must not Sleep, lest I shou'd Cuckold you in a Dream.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: A Woman may be made a Fool on, if she will; but you shall find, Mr. Watchit, I have Friends, that won't see me abus'd. Lucy, call me a Chair—I'll clear my self, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Hussey, Stir if you dare. [To Lucy.] No, Madam, you shall clear your self here, if you can.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I wou'd advise you, Sir, to agree with your Lady.— Mr. Constable, you may leave your Prisoners with me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: This is a Cause for the Civil Court.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I have something to offer under the Cognizance of Common Law; Have not we an Act against Priests, that belong to no Ambassadors?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, it's Death for such to live in England; and it's pity that Act is not put in Execution.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Then, I here deliver up this Gentleman to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: What, do you mean to Hang me for a Priest, Mistress? Am I a Priest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VV.
sp.p: So you pretended, when you took my Confession; Cou'd you imagine, I did not know you? Yes, and resolv'd to fit you for your Jealousy. And now this good Company shall judge, if I don't Bed ev'ry Night with a Fryar; and pray you, Snub, what Door in our House keeps shut, when you approach, and bid it open?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You are Bit, old Gentleman.— I suppose you'll ask my Pardon now, Sir? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: The Devil sneer you.—How have I expos'd my self! Ah! Tim! Tim! Thou art but a Fool of a Wise Man! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Oh! Cousin Headless! you'll forgive my taking up your House here.—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: My Servants told me the Reason.—You are Welcome, Sir Philip. I hate the sight of him; but it's no Time to tell him so now.—Well! I have made no ill Bargain. If this Spouse of mine shou'd never return, this Writing intitles me to all his Estate in Jamaica.— If he lives to come back— I shall be a Woman of Quality; and our Laws make farther Provision for me, if he dies. I wish all Widows were as Wise as my self. Cousin Olivia, Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: How go Matters here? Dear Cousin, inform me.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: As you wou'd have 'em, I believe; for the Parson was sent for; and, methinks, one may read Matrimony in Mr. Freeman's Face already.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
Ho! Are you come.
Seeing Olivia.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Did you send for me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come hither, Child.—Mr. Freeman, we had as good make an End of the Business now; and this good Company will make up a Country Dance—Here's my Girl. Cousin Headless will send for a Parson.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh miserable! What do I hear? Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: The Business will soon be done.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: My Business is done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: But not with my Daughter, Sir—Come, hang Thinking; send home the Dutch-Woman. They are heavy dull Jades! Here's a Girl of the true old English Breed, that will make you as merry as a Cricket, when the Parson has said Grace, Boy.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir Philip, I have more Occasion for the Hangman's Halter, than the Marriage Noose.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What! before you are Married? Pish, Pish! that's impossible — But were there not certain Articles to be perform'd on your part to Day?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I thought so Yesterday, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yesterday, Sir! Zounds! What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, in short, Sir, This Lady has stept in between my Brother Ned, and your Daughter, and supply'd her Place; that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O Bless'd Sound! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What, have you another Play to Act, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, Faith, Sir Philip, the Play is ended; and, with your leave, this Lady and I will speak the Epilogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
Stark Mad, by Jupiter! Hold, hold, hold, Sir; this Lady do's not understand Epilogues,
nor Prologues neither [Takes her from him] Do you think I am to be fool'd, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: No, Sir; But I think you must look out sharp for another Son-in-Law, Sir Philip; for I am on the Right-side the Hedge, now—We are Married, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Indeed! Is she in Earnest, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, Faith, I can see no Jest in't; and I'll tell you another Secret; I have given my Brother every Foot of my Estate.—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Really!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Really, Sir Philip. I drew the Deed.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Why then it was the worst Deed he ever did in his Life: And, if it be true — I wish you Joy, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To convince you, Sir, there's the Papers.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Humph—'Tis even so—I wish you Joy with your Dutch Vrow, Mr. Freeman— I do, Faith, Minheer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: My Lover Married! Nay, then I'm glad we were no better acquainted. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I wish you Joy, Madam.
To Louisa.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: It is not in the Power of Fortune to give me more. I hope, my Dear, you are pretty well again.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Humph! My Sickness will continue longer than she imagines. [Aside.] You assure me, I'm in no Danger of leaving the World, Madam; I wish you cou'd tell me how to live in't.—

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Oh! trust to Love, my Dear!

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And Starve, my Dear! Walks from her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How shall I be able to look my Wife in the Face again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Methinks, Lucy, your Master seems to have an Air of true Penitence.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He does, indeed, look Penitential, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
I've been considering you from Head to Foot, Sir John; and, upon my Soul, I think
I never saw you look so well in all my Life: Tho', to say Truth, I always thought you a fine Gentleman.— 'Till he was Disinherited. [Aside.] — Olivia, Come hither, Child! Give me thy Hand; It was ever my Resolution, that thou shou'dst go with the Estate; and therefore, Sir John, since you've got one, e'en take t'other. [Throws her to him.] — There, now do your Endeavour to make me, within Ten Months, a Grandfather.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: On my Knees I thank you. This Present is more Welcome, than what my Brother gave me.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Return my Deed then; I did not give it you: You trick'd me out of it; Remember that, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Out of nothing, but my own, Brother; but half my Estate is at your Service. Your Generosity to this Lady commands that.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir? Then your Generosity shall command but half my Daughter's Portion; Mark that.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I Bar that Injustice; the Fortune's all his own; Nor do we need your kind Indulgence, Brother.—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No! — Egad, I'm glad to hear that! Aside.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Yours was the Plot that made my Freeman mine; and Heaven Rewards you for't, with your Estate; and puts it in my Pow'r to raise your Brother above the Reach of Want. Know, then, My Father left me his only Heir, and Mistress of Forty Thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha! Say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I knew not where to find thee; but resolv'd to live Unmarried for thy Sake.— But, upon Sir John's Letter, hasten'd to prevent thy Breach of Faith. 'Tis done; forgive the Artifice, and all my Fortune's thine.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Forgive thee! What, Forty Thousand Pounds, and ask Forgiveness! One Quarter of the Money wou'd purchase a Pardon for all the Sins of thee, and thy Posterity! I affirm, no Woman can be Guilty of any Fault, that has Forty Thousand Pounds—But
few of thy Sex can boast such Constancy. How shall I thank thee for this excessive Goodness?—Brother! Let me thank you too. Had I known your Inclination for this Lady, you shou'd have had no Rival here. Claps his Hand on his Breast.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: And if he had not got the Estate again, he shou'd have had no Father here. [Clapping his Hand on his Breast] Come, come, 'tis all well, and the Man has his Mare again.—What are you musing on, Sir? [To Watchit] Prithee be chearful Man—Suppose you were a Cuckold, the Fault's not yours, nor your Wife's neither: No doubt but you was born when Mars and Venus were in Conjunction; and if so, who can withstand their Fate?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ha, ha; But this Gentleman is in no Danger—Come, come, Sir, take your Lady, and make much of her; give her her own Liberty; confide in her Honour, and that way secure her Vertue.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I'm glad the old Cuff does not know me again. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Let him cease to be Jealous, and when I give him real Cause, let him expose me.—What say you, Mumps? Shall I enjoy the Liberties of an English Wife?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I'll from this Moment banish all my Cares,
With all my Locks, and Bolts, and Iron Bars.

div.stage: Enter Fainwell, and Sam, singing, the last with a Bottle and Glass in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Bless me! what do I see? my Rascal Drunk?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Jeffery in his Cups?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ay! I'm resolv'd to be merry to Night, bemess, Sir.— Sings.

div.stage: Sing Ola wa, Let us be merry—

p.hi: O nilly wa, Let us be merry.
And drink the King's Health in racy Canary.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ya hony Lee.—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I'll hony Lee you, Sirrah— Runs to beat him.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my Dear; tho' I allow'd you to beat me, when you was my Mistress, the Case is alter'd now you are my Wife—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Wife!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I am no longer Jeffery! but your Lord and Master.—

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Ruin'd past Redemption! Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: No, no, my Dear, I'll so Hug, Love, and Buss thee, that thou shalt own to Morrow Morning thy Money well laid out. [Goes to Embrace her.]

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Stand off; I never can forgive you putting such a Trick upon me, Mr. VVorthy!

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Mr. Fainwell, if you please, my Dear. You shall find me a Man of Honour. You know, it was part of our Agreement, you shou'd not be call'd Mrs. VVorthy.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Not VVorthy! Oh Heavens! then I have Married a down-right Scoundrel! Oh! undone, undone; get out of my Sight. Oh! oh.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p:
Get out of thy Sight! No, no, I'll get into thy Arms, my Girl; where I'll convince thee, that I'm a Gentleman, of a better Family than your Sham-Lord.
VVhispers Sam, who Exits.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: That he is, I assure you, Widow; for he is my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: A very odd Metamorphosis! You are an Excellent Actor, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ev'ry Man in his Way, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Is your Vanity come to this! Faith, you have made but a blind Bargain of it, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: You had like to have couzen'd her into a blinder Bargain—Hark-ye, Sir Philip, what was you to have had, if this Noble Lord of your Dubbing, had been in my Place?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What do you mean by asking that Question, Sir? Do you think I was to be Brib'd?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: So this honest Gentleman says, Sir; to the Tune of Three Thousand Pounds.—Is it not true, Tally?

sp.speaker: Tally.
sp.p: To a Tittle, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Why, you, you, you impudent Son of a Whore; were not Seventeen enough for you?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Not if he had been what you represented him, Sir. But I have nothing to thank your Friendship for.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: A Fig for your Reflections; nothing wou'd go down with your Vanity, but a Lord, forsooth; and since no Lord of the King's making wou'd be troubled with you, I made one on purpose for you. Look-ye, 'tis my Opinion, ev'ry Man Cheats in his way—And he is only Honest, who is not discover'd.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fain.
Tally.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir.—And I am glad I'm come off so well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam, I think you have 'scap'd very well, considering all. You might have been undone: The Prevention of which is owing to Mr. Fainwell. There's nothing in a Title—Believe me, there are more heavy Hearts in Coaches with Coronets behind 'em, than you'll find in the Hacks, take 'em as they run, from the Royal Palace to the Royal Exchange.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
I'm of my Brother's Opinion, Madam; Mr. Fainwell bears the King's Commission; and tho'
he is but a Subaltern, you have Fortune enough to buy him a Regiment; and a Colonel's Lady is as good as my Lord's.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Well, since it is no better; 'tis well it's no worse—But don't you think, Sir John, a Thousand Pounds, rightly plac'd, wou'd not get him Knighted?

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! We'll consider of that to Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I hope you'll forgive the Blows, I —

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: And promise never to return 'em too.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nephew, I wish thee Joy with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Fain.
sp.p: I thank you, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'm so much indebted to you, that I love you now, methinks, in spight of Principle.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: My Principle, dear Jack, is the same with thine. I did not think it prudent to contradict my Father; but no Man shall do more in Defence of his Country, or pay his Taxes more chearfully. Come to my Arms —

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To my Heart. They Embrace.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p:
Now every Man to his Mate; and let's have a Country Dance
Goes to Louisa.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Watchit, take your Wife, and let me advise you, if she has any Faults, hide them from the Publick:
sp.l: For He or She, who drags the Marriage Chain,
And finds in Spouse Occasion to complain,
Should hide their Frailties with a Lover's Care,
And let th' ill-judging World conclude 'em Fair;
Better th' Offence ne'er reach the Offender's Ear.
For they who Sin with Caution, whilst conceal'd,
Grow impudently Careless, when reveal'd.

lg.l: SINCE Plotting is the Business of the Age,
Our Bard has paid it off upon the Stage,
And strongly labour'd in these Scenes, to show ye,
How Woman can in Artifice out-do ye.
You Bungle sadly, and are always Caught,
E'er half your Work is to Perfection brought.
Did our Town-Wives their Schemes no better lay,
What Monstrous Plots wou'd break out ev'ry Day?
Ladies, I hope, I've acted to your Mind,
And serv'd my Jealous Monster in his Kind.
To play the Priest, and steal a Wife's Confession;
What Man can make Amends for such Transgression?
Shou'd all our English Husbands Shrive their Wives,
Women wou'd lead most Comfortable Lives.
For of all Slavery, 'tis the worst Condition,
To Live beneath a Marriage Inquisition.
What think you of our Hogan-Mogan Belle?
Didn't she trick the Trickster nicely well?
The Whipster thought, forsooth, 'twas smart and clever,
To swell the Young Vrow up, and then to leave her.
But on the Younker a Dutch Trick she palms;
Poison for Poison gives, and Qualms for Qualms.
What Rake among you, but, in his Condition,
Wou'd ev'n think a Wife a good Physician?
Did this Dutch Law our roving Gentry bind,
How Charming wou'd it be for Woman-kind!
Then ev'ry Nymph that has vouchsaf'd the Favour,
Might tye her Lover up to good Behaviour:
And after she has put him to the Test,
Might take, or leave him, —as she lik'd it best.
You who are Noos'd, let me advise; Beware,
Give o'er your Jealous Freaks, and trust the Fair:
For, look-ye, you may Rant, and play the Devil;
There's nought but Patience cures the Marriage-Evil.
The Thing is plain, and Instances are Common;
No Man is Half a Match for any Woman.
